To do this, they need to have one place to keep all of their thoughts - a comp book. My students are amazing. They come from all over the world, and have experienced more than I can imagine. They have powerful stories to tell, and in my class, I'm trying to help them find their voices. They are funny, insightful, and more worldly than I ever was when I was their age. But they also have a lot working against them - many are migrants or refugees; most are low-income; our building lacks some of the basic necessities. We talk a lot about the adversity we experience and see, and how that makes us who we are. My goal as their language arts teacher is to help them find out more about who they are, what they've experienced, and how their stories can change those around them. It's daunting for all of us, but exciting when a student realizes that she isn't just doing a writing assignment, but instead is telling something personal and teaching me about her. We use comp books as a 'writers' notebook.' This is a space that's entirely the student's: it's personalized, and will end up holding all of the work that they'll do for the whole year. At times I'll ask them to write very specific things; other times, it will be a space dedicated to free writes, opinions, ideas, and reservations. A writer's notebook is critical for writers, regardless of their level, and we want our students to start embracing their identities as writers early on. Therefore I am asking for composition notebooks, folders in which to store the books, and pencils for writing.A writer's notebook is critical for writers, regardless of their level, and we want our students to start embracing their identities as writers early on. My hope is that these books will become a habit of work for them as they continue with their lives, and they'll make habits of reflecting, writing, processing, and thinking about their lives through their writing.
needStatement: My students need basic like composition books as 'writers' notebooks' and folders to keep important papers in.

name: Play-Doh, Ducks, Balls and More!
description: We strive to stay on green, and have earned a trip to our FABULOUS, but empty treasure box. This year, in my 29th year of teaching, I will be teaching the English portion of our school's newly implemented, Spanish Immersion program. This means I will have a total of 44 wonderful first-grade learners, with two classes of 22 students. I will be responsible for teaching reading skills to both groups of students. Both groups of students will be striving to stay on green, to earn a trip to the treasure box. This means we will need lots and lots of treasure box rewards! Everyday my students strive to stay on green. They can achieve this by demonstrating appropriate behavior, making good choices, being a good friend, and by putting forth effort, to work to their fullest potential. At the end of the month those students that have stayed on green everyday are able to select a prize from the treasure box. My kids have completely bought into this system, and work so hard to be good, positive students. Unfortunately, our treasure box selection is running low, and expenses for reward items can be very costly. With your support I can replenish our treasure box stock with some awesome new prizes, such as a variety of playdoh cans and play doh tools. My kids absolutely love working with play-doh. It is a great fine motor tool, that kids can use for educational or fun activities. I have also selected some other items such as puffer balls, parachute men, and other fun rewards. Our treasure box needs to be restocked, but it is so costly to provide 44 students with rewards. With the play doh and other treats, my students will be so excited to earn their monthly reward!
needStatement: My students need playdoh, playdoh tool sets, and a variety of other treasure box treats.

name: Play-Doh Helps Us Learn Our Letters!
description: 'Tell me and I forget. Teach me and I remember. Involve me and I learn.' Benjamin Franklin Our special education students needs hands-on learning with play-doh to help them create letters, and manipulate phonemes. Our school is a title 1, Pre-K to 5th grade, elementary school in Brooklyn. We have a large population of English Language Learners and students with special needs. Our programs include inclusion English Language Learners classes, ELL pull-outs, ICT classes, 12 to 1 special education classes, dual language and gifted and talented programs. Our teachers work hard to meet the needs of each and every individual student, meeting their educational and personal needs to the best of our ability. 'Tell me and I forget. Teach me and I remember. Involve me and I learn.' Benjamin Franklin Our Play-Doh project will put play-doh in the hands of our pre-k classes and special education Kindergarten and grade 1 classes to help them learn through hands-on manipulation. Our play-doh project includes TONS of play-doh and tools to create letters, numbers and other limitless inventions. Tools such as cookie cutters, rollers, hammers and more will offer children the opportunity to create and explore the letters that comprise the language they will learn to read and speak. This project will not only benefit one class, but at least 6! Each Pre-K class and some Kindergarten and 1st grade classes will have a tool kit that will allow students to create letters with their own hands using Play-Doh and Play-Doh tools. Students will learn letters and sounds by manipulating play-doh into letters of their own creation! Help us involve our students in their own learning!
needStatement: My students need Play-Doh and Play-Doh tools to help them learn!

name: The Value of Curiosity and Choice Chambers
description: As I embark on my second year of teaching high school science, I am filled with excitement, anticipation, and a sense that I carry a heavy burden. Since many of my students will have me as their science teacher for three to four years in a row, I am solely responsible for their opinion of science. I teach at a small school in a rural agricultural community burdened with poverty. Our students grow up in single-parent homes with more mouths to feed than food on the table. Education is not valued, and it seems as if our students cannot imagine a reality in which they do not rely on government support. They are the victims of generational poverty, and my fellow educators and I are tasked with teaching them how to become productive citizens and break that cycle. As a science teacher, I feel like my role is to teach students how to ask relevant questions and determine how to answer those questions. One of the biggest themes of my classes is the importance of inquiry. Curiosity has been a major catalyst for scientific discovery, and I like to foster curiosity by allowing my students to design and carryout their own experiments. One type of experiment students can easily relate to is animal behavior. A choice chamber allows students to present an organism with several different choices and determine their preferences. For example, my students may collect pill bugs and determine what roll they play in an ecosystem by figuring out what they like to eat. When students ask their own question, design their experiment, then seek to answer that question, they are not only learning about science, they are becoming scientists. Students will then record their experimental process, show their data analysis, and present it to the class using the chart paper. Students become more confident and capable as they present their experiments throughout the year. When we celebrate curiosity and let students know they have a voice, an important opinion, we build up their self worth. When we equip students to identify relevant questions, use the scientific process to answer those questions, and confidently share their findings with their peers, we are promoting ownership and responsibility. I hope these skills and traits will help our students solve real world problems when they're no longer in the classroom.
needStatement: My students need choice chambers for animal behavior experiments, wax dye to complete density demonstrations, and chart paper to record their findings.

name: Technology Presentation Cart Needed
description: My students are energized when using 21st century digital equipment in the classroom. Our local community is lovely; students came to school this year eager to learn, and eager to use all the most up-to-date digital equipment. We hope to provide what we can, but we count on the kindness of our neighbors to help support what we are not able to. Students expect to use the most up-to-date digital equipment available. Unfortunately, last year our computer cart fell and broke, so we're using a 20-year-old cart that doesn't function properly. Having a new cart will allow us to more safely use the equipment to project classroom lessons, videos, etc. onto a large surface. All our students want is to be able to access the most up-to-date digital equipment for their learning pleasure. This cart will make a great difference in the ability to project information for all to see. Thank you so much.
needStatement: My students need a cart for our computer and projection equipment.

name: Inner-City Puppet Theater
description: Our art room houses several iterations of visual art. 1st and 2nd hour is usually basic Art 1 and 2. 3rd hour is usually Video Production. By 4th hour we are either doing Digital Photography, Graphic Design or Art Appreciation/Art History. 7th hour is the new and experimental Puppet Making class. My students are from Flint, MI and the surrounding counties. Since we are an alternative to a traditional high school, we have an extremely diverse group of students. Many of my students come from poverty stricken areas and households. This is the single factor that most of my students have in common. We are about 85% free and reduced lunches. Many come from violent environments, broken and unstable home environments. We have a large number of students who feel they just don't fit in with traditional high school. Students who are openly homosexual, pregnant, extremely intelligent, or socially awkward make up a large portion of the student body. Because of the many backgrounds and the small size of our school my students have an extremely strong bond and a fierce loyalty to the school. I think we also have a tendency to be much more creative than a traditional high school. My students tend to extremely empathetic to others. We pride ourselves in being involved in our community! The two items I am requesting are specifically for our new puppet theater that we are starting this year. We will be producing both indoor and outdoor productions. The puppets will range in size from 3 feet to parade style puppets which are sometimes up to 20 feet. Our first show will be this December. It is about dreams. The show will combine live puppetry, shadow puppetry, video, live music, recorded music, lighting, sound design, narration and a smoke machine I hope! Our main puppets are in the style of Japanese Bunraku puppets as well as European Marionette Portee style puppets. This means that the puppets are very high in artistic style and creativity. These are not Muppet style. Most of the puppets will take 3 students to operate. One for the head and arm, one for the back and other arm and one for the legs. Since we will be utilizing video and overhead projections as well as live music, narration and sound effects we are in desperate need of a movie screen and a sound system. Our intention is for our students to be able to tell stories relevant to their lives. Puppets are a great way for our particular student body to express themselves in a unique way. Controlling a puppet also takes some of the stigma of performance away from an otherwise nervous young actor. Helping to support our Puppet Theater will directly impact the lives of hundreds of inner-city youth and their families but also the wider Flint community.
needStatement: My students need a portable movie screen to project video they create and for shadow puppetry. My students need a portable audio package for their puppet performances.

name: Kicking Off the Year Prepared!!
description: Having all of the supplies to successfully learn is exactly what my students need. With possessing all of their supplies, my students will need to learn how to stay organize and take care of each item. This will help my students focus on learning and take ownership of the tools they will be using. My fifth grade students will be busy this year. With standardize testing and preparing to attend middle school, they will need a successful year to build their confidence for the big switch. My students are part of a community school. A community school receives specific funding to help support each child's needs. Most students are learning English. They are sweet, excited about school, and happy to see each other every day. It is a privilege to guide their learning each and every year. My students will use these materials in a variety of ways. The book boxes are a great way to store their books and to keep organize. They will use them during literacy. The highlighters and post-it notes will be use throughout the entire day. Post-it notes are used to record thinking while reading a book. They can also be used for quick assessments or activities that involve recording class data. The highlighters are also used when we are practicing a new reading strategy, identifying information, etc. My students will also use the dry erase markers during math. Each child will be responsible for their own dry-erase marker, board, and eraser. Students will normally use these materials during whole group and small group instruction. Donations will help my students be prepared for each lesson, teach them how to stay organize, and learn how to be responsible for their own materials. Students will be engaged with these materials, which helps them focus on their learning better.
needStatement: My students need highlighters, dry erase markers, and book boxes to help with each lesson and to learn how to be more responsible.

name: The Pathfinders 6th grader family needs basic art suplies :)
description: It's the beginning of a new school year and our incoming 6th grade English/Language Arts students are going to need to set some SOARING goals to work towards this year. We're looking for some art supplies we can use to share our goals and create some art to decorate our room! Edna Brewer Middle School's students are a widely diverse population; a former assistant principal called this school a 'true microcosm of Oakland'. Our school houses students grade 6, 7, and 8 -- over 800 children and 50 educators in total. We come from all different cultural backgrounds, home environments, and past experiences. This is what makes Brewer a special place. After orientations to Edna Brewer Middle School, The Pathfinders (our 6th grade family), and our English class, students will start off the school year by looking at where we're at now and where we want to be by the end of the year. Working together, we'll use acrylic paints, brushes, and small canvases to create some beautiful art that reflects our goals so we can decorate our classroom and be inspired everywhere we look! Plus, this activity will help us get to know one another and build community -- this is essential to maintaining a healthy learning environment all year. We want our own art hanging in our classroom because this will help us feel comfortable in class and proud to be there, and because this will inspire us when need that little, tiny, extra push. '... simple creative activities are some of the building blocks of child development. Learning to create and appreciate visual aesthetics may be more important than ever to the development of the next generation of children as they grow up.' (source: pbs.org 'The Importance of Art in Child Development')
needStatement: My students need basic painting supplies so we can work in small groups to create canvas paintings that share our goals for the new school year!

name: Giving Every Child A Chance To Be An Artist!
description: 'Every child is born an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once he grows up.' -Pablo Picasso In education today, the arts are always the first programs to get cut. Donating to this project will help keep one more arts program alive . . . so every child can foster their inner artist. My students are curious, creative young minds. They have a desire to learn and experience new things. My hope for them is to explore all the avenues of art to enhance their school experience. Our school has created a culture to allow its teachers to collaborate and foster the young minds and provide opportunities to each and every student to realize their full potential. I've asked for the most basic art supplies, like paper, glue, and paint, to keep our art program going and growing. My students will learn about some of the great artists like Van Gogh, Picasso, Kandinsky, and Chihuly and will be able to recreate their masterpieces to learn the elements and principles of art. Through the donations and projects we will be able to foster the students' critical and creative thinking skills to produce 21st century learners. It will provide an opportunity for my students to continue to develop their love for the arts.
needStatement: My students need the basic art supplies like paper, glue, and paint.

name: Reeds Needed for Band: Help Us Make Music
description: My students have their instruments supplied by the district, but need reeds in order to produce beautiful music! We perform concerts with our beginner and two advanced bands. We rehearse daily and strive for the highest! My students are passionate, hard workers. The band is made up of about 170 members. Even though 96.7 percent are economically disadvantaged, these students deserve a chance to experience the best education and musical experience they can get! We are an inner city school. Our band students will use these reeds literally everyday that they are performing. Without these reeds, the band would not be able to create music! Our clarinet, bass clarinet, and saxophone students will be using them from the beginner level through the last concert of their 8th grade year!The joy and education of learning a musical instrument should not be under-valued. It helps students express themselves, work as a team, multitask, and utilize their visual, tactile, aural skills. Through these donations, you will enable our band to be the best it can be. Students learn through their experiences. Band offers them a chance to accomplish something beautiful, as a team. They start from learning just one note, to playing entire concerts. This helps them feel good about themselves and everything they can accomplish.
needStatement: My students need 14 reeds in order to perform on their clarinets, bass clarinets, alto, tenor, and baritone saxophones! These reeds are vital to their musical experience.

name: A Bundle Of Back-up Ink Cartridges Needed!
description: How can students print their digital creations without ink in the printer? Students in the Technology and Humanities Academies are very creative. They love to use digital devices to create projects to demonstrate their new-found knowledge. We have an HP SmartPrinter, but always need fresh ink to fulfill the student needs. Students will be creating projects on their iPads or Macs in our computer lab. Now, they'll need to be able to print out these projects on the classroom printer. Sometimes we can't request they print at home, as home printers are also out of ink! Please help us get ink cartridge back-ups. Thank you so much for considering donating to my classroom printer. Students will really appreciate being able to print at-will when their projects are ready instead of waiting until printer ink can be filled.
needStatement: My students need ink for our classroom color printer.

name: Spelling Words Their Way
description: All of my students have their own needs that must be met. Why should they all learn the same exact words and move at the same pace? What if some students learn faster or slower than others? It is my goal for my students to learn at their own pace and get what they need out of my class. My students are a part of a low income area and are a mixture of different learning abilities. My school is a very caring environment, and we work hard to help our students succeed. It is important to us to help all students be successful by meeting their individual needs. We want them to have the tools they need to make it in the subsequent grades to come. My students will use these materials to not only learn how to spell words, but also reading patterns. In a former district, I have used the Words Their Way curriculum and saw a priceless amount of growth in my students. My current students will be able to have an individualized spelling list that they follow. This way if there are students that are struggling with a certain spelling pattern, then they can continue working on it. On the other hand, a student may have an easier time with learning how to spell and needs a challenge. Then you have students that fall in the middle and need consistency. This program offers the ability to meet all of these students' needs and raise their reading skills as well. They are not competing with other students, but rather trying to improve their progress. This project will change my students' lives by giving them confidence. They will no longer feel the competition with other students that may always get things right, but rather feel a sense of accomplishment in their ability to improve. It also provides them with reading skills that are necessary to be successful.
needStatement: My students need the Words Their Way spelling curriculum so that they can learn how to spell words at their own pace.

name: Graphic Novel about Cells
description: My class if very diverse and has many different levels of abilities. I want my students to have a love for science and to know how to discover things on their own. My biggest challenge is their motivation to read. The graphic novel The Basics of Cell Live will help my students today and tomorrow. My students come from an inner city environment who have very close ties to their family and friends. They are very energetic and like to go outside and learn and do hands on activities. The school has children in kindergarten to 8th grade. My students have a huge influence on the younger ones. The graphic novel is a piece of literature that the students will be able to understand because the information is linked to illustrations. The text book is not engaging and the students do not retain information from it. This novel is entertaining, its a story about an adventure and it is at most of their reading levels. The novel The Basics of Cell Live with Max Axiom will help improve my classroom because all children need to read and teaching them that there is many things out there to read than text books is important. I want my students to read not because they have to but because they want to.
needStatement: My students need a piece of literature (The Basics of Cell Life with Max Axiom, Super Scientist) that will engage them. Since the main content of the class is about cells this graphic novel will be popular!

name: Showcasing Our Work!
description: 'Use what talents you possess. The woods would be very silent if no birds sang there except those that sang the best.' - Henry Van Dyke I want my students to be proud of the work that they do day in and day out. Being able to showcase it helps build confidence and create peer models. I have a classroom of 25 students who are fun-loving and hard-working. Many are English language learners, many are special education, and most (approximately 90%) qualify for free or reduced lunch. These students come to school excited for learning, and love to get their hands on anything that will help increase their learning. Beyond these odds, my students work hard to achieve a level one status, and are fabulous human beings. These students are excited to learn, and absolutely love learning. The resources being requested are simple, printer ink and construction paper. Posting classroom models and 'star work' in the classroom not only promotes what goals each student should be working to achieve, but builds self-confidence in students. In my classroom, I ensure to frequently rotate role model work, and highlight different features so each student gets a chance at one point or another to be a star student. My students are working hard, and I want them to be proud of the amazing things they are accomplishing. Students can always learn from each other, and many love having a peer model from someone that they know. By having printer ink to be able to print out their work and construction paper to post the work on, students can 'show off their genius' and be proud of the things they are accomplishing! By making a donation, you will help my students to be proud of the work they are accomplishing and be willing to share it. Teaching in a special education inclusion room, many of my students lack self-confidence and rarely share. By giving them this chance and an environment in which they will feel safe, students will share and excel beyond their wildest dreams!
needStatement: My students need ink and construction paper to publish and showcase their work.

name: Experiencing the Sights and Sounds of the Civil War
description: Most of my students are on the Autism spectrum and are visual learners. Bringing them to a Civil War reenactment would help them to learn about and understand the Civil War. My classroom consists of students with significant learning handicaps. Although they are in high school, they learn at an elementary school level. Visual aids and hands-on experiences seem to be the most effective means of achieving understanding and interest. My students are learning all subjects, including social skills and functional skills. My students need to attend a Civil War reenactment experience to bring history to life. This would be a once-in-a-lifetime experience for the majority of my students. I have attended the Civil War reenactment, and I am positive that this field trip would be one that they will not soon forget. Not only will they get to see the Blue and the Gray at battle, they will also get to go through an encampment and see how Civil War soldiers lived during that time. By donating and enabling my students to attend the Civil War reenactment, you will be providing an amazing learning experience that no textbook or film could ever come close to achieving.
needStatement: My students need to attend a Civil War reenactment experience to bring history to life.

name: Rolling Cart for Document Camera
description: We are in the 21st century and electronics is where our world is going towards. Our school PTA purchased us document cameras, but unfortunately I do not have a place to store them where there is easy access. My room is not big enough. My school is located in the inner sunset of San Francisco, where English is the second language for almost half of the kids. 50% of our population qualify for free/ or reduced lunch. They are eager learners and the focus of our school is academics. My students come from all areas in San Francisco, some even bussed from the other side of town. With the rolling cart, I will be able to move it around the room for usage when I need to use the document camera. My room is not big and there is not enough space to put it in a stationary table. For kindergarten, we have center tables, a big rug, reading area, play area, art area. I need something where I can have easy access in maneuvering the cart around. With the cart, it will not be in the way where kids can bump into or trip over the cords because it will be put to the side when it is not in use. When it is in use, the children will be seated and listening attentively during the lesson.
needStatement: My students need a rolling cart for the document camera.

name: Ink For Health Stations
description: My students need to learn about healthy habits. Students learn best by hands-on activities. We need to have our students working in learning stations! Materials are expensive. To save money, we can print our own activities. However, we need ink to do so. My students are curious first graders who attend a Title I school. Almost 79% of our school's students qualify for free or reduced price lunch services. Our school system just doesn't have the funds to provide our students with the resources they need to succeed. With the donation of the ink, I could make wonderful learning health stations to differentiate the instruction for each level of my students. My students will be able to work in groups as well as independently. In addition, my students can print off certificates and projects they complete in class. Students need to learn about nutrition at an early age so that they can have a healthy future. With your help my students will have a better learning experience through wonderful health stations.
needStatement: My students need ink and toner to print activities for health stations.

name: Learning Social Skills through Play
description: 'If you never did, you should. These things are fun, and fun is good.' Dr. Seuss. If you come into my classroom you will see 25, engaged Kindergarten students, who are learning at a high level, and having a blast. I believe in making my lessons as engaging and fun as possible. My students come from a variety of economic backgrounds. Many of my students speak a language that is not English at home. My students come into Kindergarten at a variety of levels. Some have attended preschool prior to coming to kindergarten, but the majority have not. Kindergarten is most of my students' first formal educational experience. Our community was recently hit with a traumatic natural disaster, and it has brought the community closer together. I am requesting an organization system and toys, such as, Lincoln Logs, Play-Doh, and Legos, for my students to use during free choice time. These toys will allow my students to gain social and academic skills, while having fun. My students will use the materials requested to gain fine motor skills, learn turn taking, and make new friends. If you walk into my classroom during Free Choice time, you will see my students playing with these toys, having a blast, and using problem solving skills. This project will allow my students to feel a sense of community. When students play together, they learn acceptance, and many social skills that they can use throughout life. Some of these skills include patience, friendship, and turn taking.
needStatement: My students need toys to support social skills. They need block sets, dishes, and cars to use during free choice time to increase social skills and promote creativity.

name: Seeing Rainbows With Much Needed Supplies
description: 'When you reduce life to black and white, you never see rainbows.' -Rachel Houston My desire is for my students to see rainbows this school year, but we need the supplies to make that happen. My 60+ third graders attend a Title I (low socioeconomic) school in Texas. We have a wide range of students, including those who come from middle class families to those whose parents struggle to make ends meet. Despite their diversity, ALL of my students are inquisitive learners and hard workers. As their math teacher, I love working with them and watching them discover how mathematics is an integral part of their everyday life. We received a printer through donorschoose.org last year, but printers require ink. And with the new school year here, we are in need of more ink! Having ink means that I can print colorful foldables and anchor charts for my students' interactive math notebooks. I can also create more activities and games for Math Workshop. We are also in need of a VGA Manual Switch Box. We received an iPad stand through donorschoose.org last year as well, which has allowed me, the teacher, to use my district-provided iPad as a document camera. That has been a huge help in the classroom, allowing all of my students to see the lesson for the day. Currently, to switch back and forth between the iPad and computer when using the projector, I am constantly unplugging and plugging back in. Not only is it a waste of class time, but it often messes up the display--sometimes not working at all! Having the VGA switch box would allow me to connect both pieces of technology without all of the mess. My classroom has been blessed by the generosity of the donorschoose.org community, and having received various resources has made a huge difference in both my teaching and my students' learning. What we are asking for now would allow us to continue to use what we already have in a more efficient and effective manner. I don't want my students to live in a black and white world in my classroom, and with your help, these supplies will help them see rainbows.
needStatement: My students need both black and color ink cartridges as well as a VGA Manual Switch Box.

name: Preparing the Less Fortunate for Success in Independence
description: 'If you think my hands are full, you should see my heart'I just want the best for my students. My typical day is 3-80 minute blocks of preparing students for the real world without proper materials & supplies. At the end of the year, I would like my students to feel comfortable with their independce I have around 40 students who are learning disabled. They range in abilities including: ADHD, Autistic, Specific Learning Disabled and Behavior Disabled. My students are kind and caring and deserve the best education. My school is located in an inner city and my students struggle with the the hardships that living an inner city brings. My classroom is my students safety net, this is where they come for love, consistence and encouragement. I have the motivation and the creative mind but lacking the funds that I need to help my students. With all of the supplies I have asked for it will help my students learn life and employment skills. The document camera will help students learn from others; see their mistakes and see how they can do something a different way. The cash register; will prepare students and make them skilled for an entry level job. The refrigerator; will prepare my students for independent living of food shopping and making sure items are used and thrown away if food expires. Colored printer; to help guide and aide students in task analysis. Color coded work for students who may need it. Tablets; will help monitor students growth in every day computer skills. My students will benefit from each and every one of these items! These donations will help my classroom by giving my students the materials and supplies they need to gain an independent life style. It will change my students' lives because by having these items they will feel the love and care from the donors and feel honored to be given these items. By being an inner city, they do not get much attention, so this will definitely motivate them to learn.
needStatement: My students need a document camera, colored printer, a tablet, a refrigerator, and an entry level cash register.

name: Ms. Mitcham's Leveled Readers
description: Our classroom is a bright, energetic, and interactive place to be! We stay very busy in kindergarten, and every year and I amazed by how quickly and how much the students grow and learn in a year. One of my goals is to help my students gain a love for books and for reading! My school has a great community and wonderful students. The parents are very important and eager to help in their child's education. Most of my students are very smart and eager to learn, especially when it comes to reading. They have so much joy and pride in themselves when they read their first book. My school has a great community feel and all the teachers, staff, and parents work very hard to educate our students. Right now I have a small collection of leveled books for my students. My goal is to add more quality leveled books to my library for the students to read independently every day. The students will 'shop' for books and choose their 'on level books' to read during independent reading time. They love to read books on their own and they gain so much confidence in their reading ability when they can read a book by themselves. I would love to have a wide variety of books for them to choose from. This will help them gain more exposure to books and hopefully continue their growth in their reading ability. This donation would be very beneficial to my students now and for years to come. It will improve my quantity and quality of leveled readers in my own classroom library. This will give my students more opportunities to read books that they can read on their own and will give them more exposure to a variety of literature. Most books are 'fun' books but these leveled books are books that are on the student's own personal reading level, giving them more confidence to read more books.
needStatement: My students need a variety of leveled books to meet their individual reading needs. My students need levels D,E,and F to meet their independent reading level.

name: We Are Growing as Readers -- Classroom Library Expansion
description: Practice makes perfect is a common phrase that we hear and it is so helpful in reading too! So, in a 2nd grade reading classroom it is necessary to have books available for all students to practice their reading. My students are second graders that are immersed in reading everyday. I teach two classes of students, so I work with about 44 students each day. I teach reading through a readers workshop model. This allows me to work with students in whole group, small group, and individually. The books I am requesting would become part of my classroom library. These books are used for independent reading time in class. Independent reading time is a time frame where students are reading on their own, with a purpose. I conference with students independently and am able to discuss reading strategies with the students. By building the classroom library, students have more books to use during independent reading time and continue to grow as independent readers. The requested items will help build my classroom library and will help build student's reading stamina and enjoyment of reading. The expanded library will offer a variety of fiction and nonfiction books for 2nd grade readers.
needStatement: My students need a variety of new books to help broaden my classroom library. These books are high interest and will help build independent readers.

name: Basler's Wish List Books
description: Experts say a classroom library should have 20 books per student. I have 2 classes of 21 students. This means I will need approximately 1,000 books in my library to meet the needs of my readers. My students select books to read once a week. They choose 3 on their reading level and 2 free choice . Students at our school, and specifically in 2nd grade, are motivated and want to do their best. Their parents are very supportive! Many of them have after school activities which add to their interest on a variety of topics: sports, music, etc. Most of their parents are higher-educated. Many have lived overseas. My students read approximately 45 minutes per day. They choose books on their reading level and also get free choice. The high interest books will be motivating and help students to read more and more! They will get better at reading with my guidance, instruction, and conferring with each individually. As I confer with each one, I can guide my instruction to meet their needs and help them improve their fluency. They will learn a variety of topics, because I will be choosing sets which are nonfiction, fiction, biographies, mysteries. My goal is to make students life-long readers. As they learn to choose appropriate books, they will enjoy reading and want to read! I am able to give them time to read, so they need books that are interesting to them, can be read fluently, and comprehended adequately.
needStatement: My students need to have independent reading time to practice reading. Books which are high interest and appropriate reading level will enable them to enjoy reading.

name: Help! Financial Literacy Materials to the Rescue!
description: Each day, my fifth graders and I meet with a handshake or high five. A big challenge my students have this year is that there is a new financial literacy unit and currently we have few materials to help them succeed. My hope is that they will grow in learning and in character this year. My students attend a Title I school in Spring ISD. My school is home. It's a place where our students know they are safe and loved. I love working with such passionate teachers that love their students and choose everyday to pour into their lives. I teach fifth grade math and it's exciting and new each day! My students enjoy acting out little math problems, reading stories that connect literature to their current topic in math. We look forward to a new year and to studying new TEKs as well. My classroom is very hands on. I believe these materials will bring math to life! Students see cash registers every day. What better way to learn about money and payment methods than letting them control the system with their own register! My students will practice and connect real life procedures, like going to the store or paying for a toy online, with these hands on activities. They will practice writing checks to one another, paying with a debit card, and counting out money. They will learn about taxes, penalties, making a budget, and the many different types of payment options. My students need fictional stories, play checks, and debit/credit cards so that they can connect financial literacy to real life, in an interesting and fun way. Your donation will help make math real and alive for my students. They will become excited and joyful to attend class and learn in such a hands on way. Their communication and academic vocabulary will skyrocket while working in centers and personal time with the materials.
needStatement: My students need fictional stories, play checks, and debit/credit cards so that they can connect financial literacy to real life, in an interesting and fun way.

name: Let's Do The Hokki Pokey and Turn Our Health Around! Part 2
description: Do you know what it is like to need to finish work, write a paper, read a story . . . When all you want to do is put your left leg in and shake it all about? I teach first grade. It is difficult for a first grader to sit still for long periods of time. And let's face it, should a first grader really sit still for that long? Hokki stools provide constant movement while the student 'sits' to complete work or explore concepts. The movement of the stool promotes physical well-being and balance to encourage a healthy lifestyle. These stools also promote intellectual well-being as the constant movement helps students focus. My students need three Hokki stools to provide movement and promote health in terms of both intellectual and physical well-being. A hokki stool is designed to give the person sitting on it constant slight movement. This helps the child get the movement they need while sitting at their seat. They are able to have a longer period of focus time to complete more work and learn in an environment that is suited to their needs. Your donation will help ensure that my classroom is equipped with Hokki stools to promote healthy lifestyles for both physical and intellectual well being. Please help my kids do the Hokki pokey and turn our health around. Helping kids...That's what it's all about! Yeah!
needStatement: My students need three Hokki stools to provide movement and promote health in terms of both intellectual and physical well-being.

name: Book donation through Donors Choose
description: Every day, my students will be allowed to read from Just Right books! My favorite quote by Frank Serafini, 'There is no such thing as a child who hates to read, there are only children who have not found the right book.' I believe they need many books to choose from. Many of my students are brand new to our country! So, they need to start like beginning readers, from easy readers. Therefore, I need more books at their levels. Our school is pretty affluent, and I believe many students' parents will donate money for these books. Each and every day my students will have time to independently read from books that are on their level. In order to do that I need many lower level books as I switch to a different grade level this year. Students will become better thinkers as they read books that are interesting to them. The donations that I receive will help my students be much more successful. In order to comprehend, students need an opportunity to read, and to enjoy it they need interesting books. By having more books in the classroom, I feel they'll be more successful!
needStatement: My students need a variety of books to read during independent reading time.

name: Building Classroom Libraries & Lifelong Readers!
description: How do you get better at something? Practice, of course! Reading is no different from playing the piano or being a soccer all star-- all three require practice and a lot of it! Our school is located just outside of Houston, Texas. In total, our school consists of 810 students, 150 of which are in fourth grade. Half of the teachers on our seven person team teach math and science, while the other half teach reading and writing (our seventh teacher is self-contained, teaching all subjects). We are appreciative of the generous parents we have at our school, many of whom offer much of their time and support. Imagine a classroom where reading is a priority and giving time to read, lots of time to read, is carved into each day. Students in our classes spend at least 30 minutes per day reading books they select on their own and are interested in. Experts say that a classroom library should have enough books to equal at least 20 per student. Because we have seven classes of readers, this would mean that our fourth grade would need over 3,000 books between our four classroom libraries to truly meet the needs of our readers. Each week, our students select new books to read. These books need to be of high interest to them as well as on their level. Having access to a wide variety of appropriate level and high interest books will aid our students on their journey to becoming lifelong lovers of reading. ÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂStudents will read if we give them the books, the time, and the enthusiastic encouragement to do so. If we make them wait for the one unit a year in which they are allowed to choose their own books and become readers, they may never read at all. To keep our students reading, we have to let them.' -Donalyn Miller, The Book Whisperer
needStatement: My students need a variety of books that are both high interest and an appropriate level with which to practice reading.

name: Can You See The Excitement?
description: 'Your life does not get better by chance, it gets better by change.' -Jim Rohn. Sitting and listening or moving and doing which would you choose? Students I work with love to learn with visuals and hands-on projects. Exciting and engaging students in learning is my goal! My students want to do well in school and prove to others that they can work along side everyone else around them. My students need lessons to be differentiated so that they can display their knowledge. I work at a title 1 school. Our district is shared with the Onondaga Nation. We have a very diverse group of learners in our district. Many of the students I work with have very little support from home and come to school seeking structure and a helping hand. When the students are given hands-on materials to create with they get excited about the activity and forget that they are learning. They quickly are engaged and ready to write, read or discuss ideas when they have their project in front of them that they just created. If every topic can be attached to a hands-on project then these students are unstoppable! With these Quill materials we will be able to accomplish several activities. The bulletin board materials will be a great visual connection for the students during our Dr Seuss celebration unit. Students start to engage in discussions about the stories and make connections to stories they have read by Dr Seuss. The fish bank will be a craft related to the fish in the Dr Seuss stories. We will us the banks for storing rhyming words we learn, and descriptive writing pieces will be written about the fish they have created. They will also be carried over to our math unit involving money. The styrofoam balls will be used as decorations at Christmas time where students will design an ornament and then write a poem that goes with the project. Students will be able to wrap their ornament and give it to someone as a gift. This project will go along with our poetry unit and what it means to share the gift of giving. The donations to this project will help to improve the students excitement of learning and coming to school. The hands-on projects and visuals keep their brains moving and wheels turning. When there is something concrete in front of them it is amazing the work that is produced with very little hesitation. They love to show off their projects to others. These materials will help the students build their self confidence and be proud of what they have accomplished.
needStatement: My students need craft supplies such as glitter, styrofoam balls, sequins, beads, straight pins, fish bank kits and a Dr Seuss bulletin board set.

name: Scholastice Nonfiction Magazines
description: My classroom is full of energy. Engaging in reading does not have to be a passive, silent activity. Every day adults read the news through magazines, newspapers and periodicals and then engage in conversations regarding what they read. I want my students to share this experience with their classmates! My students are part of a small community. They are interested in current events and what role they play in their community. I would describe my school as an exciting place to learn and a safe place to try new things. Reading nonfiction can be challenging, but with these magazines I believe I can capture more students and help with own their future discoveries in reading! In my classroom, these materials will take us out of the classroom and into the world. We will be able to receive magazines with information that they can relate to and find extremely interesting. I will use Scholastic News to practice nonfiction reading, hoping to build a platform of engaged learning. It is my hope that during our self-selected reading time I will find them selecting these materials and getting excited when I announce new issues have arrived. I believe these donations will improve my project of improved nonfiction reading in several ways. I believe it will help them understand that reading nonfiction can be extremely interesting and entertaining at the same time! I believe it will change my students' lives for the better because they will discover that nonfiction materials are not boring and hold tons of information they are truly interested in learning.
needStatement: My students need subscriptions to Scholastic News magazine.

name: Stopping To Smell The Texas Bluebonnets!
description: ' Maybe this is why we read, and why in moments of darkness we return to books: to find words for what we already know. ' Alberto Manuel. Books for my students are like a vacation in imagination. Students become life long readers through the experiences they have in elementary school. Our little school in nestled in Spring Branch. My students are eager to dive into rich literature and interact with each other as readers. Our diverse readers come from all over the world. We have Hispanic, Dutch, African-American, Japanese, and Anglo-American. Our school is committed to every learner to become a reader. With the provided authentic literature in the students' hands, students are able to discuss higher order thinking with peers. Students reading a book alone is not enough. Social discussion about elements of book increases reading comprehension and reading motivation. Students are more motivated to read when holding a brand new book in their hands. As students' minds of the 21st Century are evolved unlike ever before, so are the texts of which students are reading. Students need current books to keep their interest.
needStatement: My students need rich novels from the Texas Bluebonnet Award List.

name: Here's my Spiel....Glockenspiel That is...
description: My students love playing instruments, we just don't have enough. Physical playing time is reduced, and student learning is limited. My students learn through singing, movement, speech, creating and performing on instruments. 'Tell me, I forget, show me, I remember, involve me, I understand' (Orff). I teach 600 students in grades K-5 and they come to me for 45 minutes once a week. My school is a Title I school in a military town. Military families many times will move away due to orders or deployments, but often return 1 to 3 years later. Students at my school are eager to learn and are most excited about performing on instruments and creating and performing their own compositions. I recently certified in the Orff process and want to use this approach as a way for my students to learn. Students will learn through exploration and creating. With these glockenspiels, students will be able to improvise melodies (create on the spot), compose melodies, and accompany other students who are singing, moving, speaking or performing on other instruments. The music used in the Orff process is based on folk songs to which students have connections. They will be able to connect with students who are not from America (we have students from Yemen, China, Mexico, Columbia etc), places families have been deployed (Japan, Germany, Africa etc), and, of course, American folk music! While 2 more instruments may seem insignificant, having 2 more Orff instruments (glockenspiels) will allow more students to participate in an activity. This will reduce time and the number of groups switching out on instruments. More instruments will impact students by allowing them more learning opportunities and more time to appreciate those opportunities.
needStatement: My students need Orff instruments such as glockenspiels to use in creating and performing music.

name: Learning to READ, But Not Enough Books!
description: On a daily basis my students are using reading and writing to express themselves and ignite their excitement for lifelong learning. But, one challenge for many of my readers is finding books on their level. I also want to fill our classroom library with books to help model their writing. My class is full of young readers and writers who love to read and write on a daily basis. Our school, which is a Title I elementary school, doesn't keep books on shelves; we have books in our kids' hands daily and our books have the battle scars to prove it. My students will be using these books every day. They won't be kept in a special place for only the teacher. Instead, these books will be in the hands of kids to help improve their reading and writing skills. The books will be placed in the classroom library for independent reading and used in small groups to boost reading levels. Donating to this project will offer more choices for all readers, no matter their level. Help them improve their skills while reading and writing about books that interest them. The end goal is to develop these young minds into lifelong learners and readers.
needStatement: My students need books to use during reading and writing workshop including Brand New Leveled Readers, How Rocket Learned to Read and Ralph Tells a Story.

name: Come Listen with Me, Come Listen, Come Read Away...
description: This year, we will be taking the PARCC assessment. The assessment includes a listening portion to the assessment. We aim for our students to be successful in all parts of the PARCC and want to provide the necessary resources. Our school has currently 90% of our students eating free lunch on a daily basis. More than 50% of our students have a computer at home and therefore must come in early to school to use the school computer lab to do required homework their friends were able to accomplish at home. Despite our current issues, our students are enthusiastic and willing to try something new in order to get the best out of their education. In preparation for the PARCC, passages will be recorded by the students who have mastered reading as well as the teachers, and placed on the Apple Shuffles. Students will listen to the Shuffles and answer questions on the computer. By using the Shuffles, the students will have the opportunity to listen to the passage over and over to assist with answering the questions. Our aim is to make our students feel successful. During testing time, students normally feel at their lowest and stress out because of these high stake assessments. This project will help alleviate student stress and leave them feeling prepared when this part of the PARCC assessment approaches.
needStatement: My students need 30 Apple Shuffles.

name: To The Moon And Back!
description: Every morning I start the day with ' Are you ready to read?' and my students reply with ' Let's rock and roll!' I incorporate at least 5 read alouds a day to instill a love of reading. Not only is it important to have them leaving your class as a fluent reader but leave with a desire to read. My students are inquisitive and eager to learn. Most come from low income families and challenging backgrounds. I work at a Title 1 diverse elementary school and most of my students are ES L( English is second Language) students. Most of them do not have books at home and do not have family members to read to them. I try to make up for that at school and share my books with them so they can take that love of reading home and expose it to their parents and siblings On the very first day of school we are putting books in our students hands and exposing them to great literature. As we introduce great literature to the students to books, we add them to baskets so they then can take those books and share their excitement for reading. Even early on in Kindergarten, the students may not be able to read the words on the page but they can re-tell or picture walk a book and this builds confidence and even creativity for their writing. We will also use these books in small groups, shared groups, re-telling, exploring characters, and even in writer's workshop. Kindergarten is such an impressionable age and it is my job as a Kindergarten teacher to take these amazing books and introduce them to the world of literature. This project will enrich my classroom library so I can share my love of reading with my students My dream is that they use the skills, fluency, creativity, and expressions in reading that I have taught them and share this with the world.
needStatement: My students need numerous read aloud books so I can expose them to great literature and to help build a strong love of reading at the impressionable age of Kindergarten.

name: From Inspiration to Creation
description: Building and creating with their own hands is the best way for second graders to solidify their learning. I'm working to incorporate project based learning and hands-on reading, science and math projects in my classroom this year. My second graders are in a school where the children come from a variety of backgrounds, experiences, and socioeconomic situations. The majority of my students receive free or reduced price lunch, which means their families are struggling financially. Each year I typically have a few students with learning disabilities and special needs. For second graders, hands-on learning is key. Being able to have real life projects they can work on and create is very important. Exposure to the arts is critical for a well-rounded education. Math and Engineering are important, but without art and an ability to visualize design our engineers will be unable to create and design the vehicles, structures, and technologies of the future. My students will be able to use this die-cut printer to design and create presentations and graphs of their projects and data. It will also help students learn to visualize, apply, and create artistic designs. These skills are directly transferable to more traditional engineering projects. This will be an exciting way for them to interact with others, express their creativity, create meaning, and make memories they'll have for years to come. Most of the materials can also be used again and again throughout the years.
needStatement: My students need a Cricut Printer and die-cuts to help make posters, graphs, and presentations for their project-based learning.

name: Ms. Dixon's Vocabulary Quest
description: As a child, my family and teachers instilled in me a love for games. I hope to instill this love for games in my students, all while helping them to develop vocabulary and learn. My students come from all walks of life. They are the children of bankers, janitors, lawyers, doctors, teachers, and retail associates, to name a few. Even though they come from these various backgrounds, they are first and foremost my students. My school has an extremely low socio-economic status- 65%+ of the students receive free and reduced lunch. Some of the students here don't have access to basic necessities, so I hope to provide them with access to things that they may not have available to them outside of school- especially on the fun and educational level. Students will use the games of Scrabble and Boggle to enhance their vocabulary in every day use. Several of my students are special needs or English Language Learners. These students especially need access to ways to improve their vocabulary. Also, these games will teach students how to participate in friendly competitions, as well as group and teamwork. This will improve my classroom by providing an opportunity for students to engage in group activities, focus on building and enhancing vocabulary skills, and just have plain fun.
needStatement: My students need educational games, Scrabble and Big Boggle, that will enhance vocabulary and build knowledge.

name: Technological Classroom!
description: My classroom is an interactive classroom. My goal is to teach students to use technology and for them to use it to learn and teach those around them. Using the newest technology to do this will ensure that these students are ready for the real world- and ahead of their peers. Our school is a new charter school in Asheville, NC with an amazing vision. My classroom consists of 3 groups of the most amazing 4th and 5th graders I've ever met. Altogether about 90 kids come through the door each day. These kids are ready to learn and want (and deserve!) to use technology to do so. The projector, speakers, and Bamboo tablet (and accessories) will be used for me to present information in an interactive and engaging way. The students will also use these items to present what they learn with projects we complete throughout the year. The students will use the iPads to research and practice what we learn. These items will make research possible at school. Currently there isn't a way for students to get online. Being able to see and hear what is projected will make the lessons more interactive and fun.
needStatement: My students need iPads to do research at school, a projector and speakers to see and hear presentations, a Bamboo Pen and Tablet (like an interactive white board) to learn!

name: Global Citizens In The Making!
description: We need technology in every classroom and in every student and teacher's hand, because it is the pen and paper of our time, and it is the lens through which we experience much of our world.~David Warlock Hello and welcome to our school. It is located in the East Rogers Park area of the City of Chicago. 95% of the students population receives free or reduced lunch. Because of this, money is spent on the necessities and not on technology. This means my students do not have the same access to technology in the classroom as other schools and other students. My middle school students are eager to learn and excited to share what they have already learned. Technology in the classroom provides us with endless opportunities to both share what we have learned and to continue to learn. My goal is to prepare my middle school students for what comes after they leave my classroom and this school. In order to do that I must provide them with the tools and the opportunities to use technology on a regular basis. My Middle School students will use these Chromebooks in varying ways throughout the school year. For example, they will be able to use publication programs and software to create and publish their written work. They will be able to access the Internet, where they can conduct research, practice skills, review concepts, and learn new material. With this type of technology available at all times, my students will have access to a wide range of resources that will enhance learning and further understanding in all content areas. Students will also have an opportunity to learn how to properly use the internet to gain a perspective of the global community in which they live. By donating to this project not only will you be helping my students gain access to academic content you will also be helping these students to grow into responsible and productive global citizens.
needStatement: My students need Chromebooks in the classroom so that they can learn to become technologically savvy global citizens.

name: Let it Rain Books
description: My students love to read and I want to provide them with the best books possible. Common core is at the door and now it is essential that my students are challenged with the best books out there. These books will help pave the way. My school is the most wonderful place to learn and work in. The students are great and the teachers are a hardworking crew. My students have big hearts and really want to learn everything they can each day. Going to school each day fills me excitement because of how great of a place it is. I will use these books for read alouds, independent reading, and shared reading. I will also be adding these titles to my classroom library so students can check them out at their disposal. I will also create many interesting and fun activities for the students to complete before, during and after reading. Your donations will be changing my students lives for the better because you will be providing them with excellent and essential resource to become career and college ready- books! My school does not have enough money to provide all teachers with these materials so with your donation will of course be helping the children of one of the best schools out there! Please donate =) !!!
needStatement: My students need common core aligned books so they can become critical readers and thinkers.

name: iRead with iPods!!!!!
description: I am a first year teacher and already understand how badly my students yearn for more tech in our classroom. I have a class full of students who love to read and what better way to assist them in the very important skills they'll acquire by listening to fluent reading! My students are an amazing mix of talent, skills, and levels all across the board. They really love learning and are so eager to do so. We live in a small rural community with a huge amount of diversity, which is one of the things I adore about our district! Our classroom community is one where we respect, value, and trust each other! Imagine coming into a classroom during the reading block and seeing students engaged in learning. When you look around, you see readers sitting in the library, buddies sitting next to one another whisper reading, others at tables working with words, teachers guiding student learning, and an environment so rich in print, you want to grab a book. This is our classroom in a nutshell. By adding iPods to our classroom, the students will have the opportunity to engage in reading in a new way! Using iPods will allow them to listen and follow along with the readers words. Children love listening to reading and by focusing in on the reader, the students are given a rich, fluent example to follow in return. There are wonderful books on tape and online that have great sound effects and narrators which make listening fun. In this day and age of electronics, help make reading fun!!
needStatement: My students need 8 iPods for our Daily 5 listen to reading center to improve literacy fluency.

name: Creating Inquiry Learners
description: There can be infinite uses of the computer and of new age technology, but if teachers themselves are not able to bring it into the classroom and make it work, then it fails.ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ -Nancy Kassebaum. Our students are growing up in a technological world. Technology should be apart of their daily learning.I currently teach 3rd-6th grade gifted and talented students. Many of my students do not have access to technology at home. They are inquiry learners, and are very excited about the Problem Based Learning Units we will complete this year. My students work together on a daily basis using their cooperative and communication skills as they are researching for their PBL units. Bringing more technology in the classroom will give my students a chance to inquire about their interests, research for our PBL units, and become apart of the growing technology world without the stress of not have technology available at home. The students will use the iPad to conduct inquiry research based on their current Problem Based Learning Unit. They will also be able to connect with other teachers and students in our school through educational websites such as, Edmodo and Google Drive. Any donations to this project would be greatly appreciated, and will enhance the learning in our classroom. Students will be given the opportunity to work hands on with technology, while completing inquiry research; furthermore creating 21st century learners and enabling kids to be apart of a vastly growing competitive job market.
needStatement: My students need 1 iPad mini with case and a Rosie Revere book to conduct investigations for our Project Based Learning Units. My students need 1 engineer inspired book.

name: Researching Past, Present and Future!
description: The students at my school - and in my classroom - are diverse! Over 90% are from other countries - here as refugees. Their learning, due to language barriers, needs to involve technology (visuals) to help them close the learning gap. Learning needs to be hands-on. Hands-on requires technology. As mentioned above, the majority of our students are from war-torn countries and their families have come to the United States for better opportunities and education. Most are on free and reduced lunch and their time in school is extremely important because that is where we can help them as most of them do not have the support at home due to the language barrier. Unfortunately, learning at school cannot just come from reading a book. The students are so eager to learn and the parents are so involved - it is a joy to work at my school. The language barrier is tough, but I have had better communication at this school than my past schools! know the donation will be put to good use! We really need to use technology: visuals, examples - that can only be found online. Our school is a K-12 and we do have technology (slightly older) but to spread it between 8 grades is difficult. Often times we cannot use them because they are being used for assessments. To have a set in my classroom to use in World History - as well as my college readiness class (to do projects on careers and colleges) would help the learning immensely. I would, of course, share with the other teachers when not using them. The students are so eager! My AVID - college readiness - students will use the computers to research colleges and careers as well as complete projects. Last year they held a college fair and presented the information to the students in the lower grades and it really helped to unite the school and form a community as all the students get to know each other. Learning will be reinforced and the laptops can be used in a variety of ways to help a variety of students in multiple grades. Imagine if students are able to use a computer that works and has higher speed and is up to date? They also will see that they are worthy members of our school community and that we don't always have to have the 'reused and left-over' laptops/technology. These students will be successful members of our society and with this small contribution will make a difference!
needStatement: My students need 5 iPad minis to work on hands-on projects for world history as well as college readiness.

name: Boogie Into Reading II
description: Everything you need to know you learned in kindergarten. My students are wonderful five and six year olds that are so excited about school and learning new things. This new bunch of kids are begging for homework! Our school is a great 'family'! Often times our students come from very high poverty homes. We are a title one school located in a very rural portion of our community. The new boogie boards will be used in so many different areas in our classroom. Mainly they will be used during our small group time each day and will replace dry erase markers and boards. The kids are learning how to write letters and numbers and will be using these boards frequently. These boards are so much more exciting than pencil and paper and will eliminate the use of wasting paper. The kids in my class deserve so much than I can provide for them on my own.
needStatement: My students need 8 boogie board tablets to practice literacy skills.

name: Click, Clack, Write: Kids That Type
description: We have just moved into a new classroom this year! We need some technology, as our computer time has decreased to 15 minutes a day due to school growth! Fortunately we were able to get some iPad Minis from our amazing Donors Choose supporters! Now we need some keyboards to get full use of our iPads. I have such wonderful students! I am so surprised by their resilience and willingness to change and grow. We have already kicked off this new year and are having lots of fun. However, we are also working hard! I am impressed with my students as I get to know them. They are polite and helpful and full of joy for life and learning. Typing skills are a very important life skill! We need these keyboards to help us prepare for the future, including taking required state tests. Keyboards will give us the ability to type everyday. As we become great writers, we will also become great at typing. These two things go hand in hand in today's world. Having technology readily available to students has become more than a want. Students need to learn how to use technology responsibly and effectively. If they do not learn this as part of their education, they will be at a great disadvantage throughout their adult lives. I want my students to grow into successful and wise adults. I hope to help them on their way with the use of technology in my classroom. Please help us as we face the many challenges of moving into a new classroom!
needStatement: My students need three keyboard cases to go with our iPad Minis!

name: Molding The Future
description: My biggest challenge, in teaching kindergarten, is keeping enough fun engaging activities that make learning fun for these young minds. Sensory activities engage students and keep learning fun, so that students will be reading and problem solving with ease, by the end of the school year. In my classroom, I have 22 very wiggly, eager to learn, kindergartners from mixed and varying backgrounds. The community is very diverse. I would like to use hands on learning and play to build the team work and community skills that all students need. With a sensory table filled with moldable sand, molds, and letters, students will be able to build letters, numbers, words, names, and so much more. They will become an active part of their own education. Students will work together, and learn the value of each other and the community. This project will change the way students in my class see learning. They will not just see letters on the wall and on paper. They will be able to see the many ways that they can make and put letters, numbers, and shapes together to build part of their world.
needStatement: My students need sand, messy mats, alphabet pebbles, molds, and more for making letters, numbers, and exploring with our sensory table.

name: Literacy in Dual language
description: As a reading teacher I have discovered certain stories capture their interest, Lupita Manana is one of those books. This story of endurance and escaping poverty through education helps students understand the value of reading and school; and exposes them to beautiful writing by Patricia Beatty. My students come from a variety of backgrounds; many born in the U.S., some in a close or distant Latin American country. Dual language is a new program for my school and this is their pilot group. Together since Kindergarten (some even pre-K) there is always a shortage on materials that encourage their exposure to both English and Spanish. The goal is to help students completely bilingual in all content areas and language domains. The teacher guide materials are a great way for me to make sure I'm planning the best instruction for each learner. Students will participate in shared reading, guided reading, and independent reading using reading skills such as making inferences, summarizing, plot and character analysis. My students need a set of Lupita MaÃ±ana novels by Patricia Beatty so they are able to experience the wonders of reading stories that mirror real life situations. Students will use their interactive student notebooks to record a variety of response to text responses written after reading and discussing plot events; and character reactions. Lupita Manana is a book that has made an impact in many of my students lives; this is proven when they come back for open house or write me letters telling me how much they enjoyed the book. The themes of poverty, survival, immigration, and striving for a better quality of life by using education as a means for change resonate with students. This is literary my favorite book and I tell that to students, it is amazing how much they get into it realizing that reading is a wonderful skill.
needStatement: My students need a set of Lupita Manana novels by Patricia Beatty so they are able to experience the wonders of reading stories that mirror real life situations.

name: Math Motivation: Technology for Math Practice
description: Charles Caleb Colton wrote, 'The study of mathematics, like the Nile, begins in minuteness but ends in magnificence.' My students need practice with the minute in order to access the magnificent. My students are wonderful second graders who are eager to learn. They come from a wide variety of racial and language backgrounds and almost fifty percent of them qualify for free or reduced lunch.
