needStatement: My students need snacks for the first week of school, reusable water bottles, and adhesive labels to label the water bottles with names.

name: Little minds at Work!
description: I teach 3 and 4 year olds in a Head Start setting. These little lovelies are so full of life and excitement I love receiving hugs and good mornings when they walk in. Head Start services children with disabilities as well as under privilaged children. 80% or more of our students come from homes that qualify for financial aid of some sort and will qualify for free and reduced lunches upon entering the public school system. They come to us for a little boost in social emotional skills, exposure to literacy and math skills, extra exposure to laguage and speech, and many other things on a daily basis. We love our students dearly and want to provide them with the background knowledge and skills that will help them to succeed in public school and beyond.I teach 3 and 4 year olds in a Head Start. They come to me already behind in many areas of their gross and fine motor, academic, and cognitive developments. The materials requested will expand their experiences in building, counting, 1-1 correspondence, sorting, classifying, and so much more. By using these manipulatives during whole group, small group, and independently; my students will begin to build their number awareness which is a critical foundation for mathematics. Your generous donation helps my students to fill the gap and enter school on par with their peers. It also helps to enrich their lives by giving them a positive first experience with school concepts.
needStatement: My students need exposure to manipulatives to encourage growth in math skills, fine motor skills, and cognitive skills.

name: Moving Minds and Bodies!
description: Our school has a population of about 650 students with many coming from homes with little monetary and academic support. The focus in our school is Animation, Creation, and Design which has opened up the door to so many students who previously had struggled in school. With the programs we offer, it has engaged so many students and they have found strengths where they didn't know existed. My students come from diverse backgrounds, however, they all have one thing in common- their creativity and conscientious attitude in the classroom. I teach a group of academically advanced 2nd graders which means they are working above their current grade level. With my students' minds working at such a fast pace, it is evident that their bodies want to do the same. They all have such unique personalities and bring so much life to our classroom. My students' minds amaze me each and every day. They are such creative thinkers and are constantly thinking outside the box. However, their little bodies need to be moving. They need to be comfortable. I have been researching the idea of flexible seating and am ready to implement it into my classroom. The idea scared me at first but if my students can think outside the box, so can I! Throughout this past year, I continued to notice how much the students wanted and needed to be moving around while they are working. They loved sitting around the room over sitting in their chairs. Students showed so much more on task behavior and creativity in their work- I was amazed! This would give them the opportunity to work in a more comfortable and conducive environment to showcase their work. Currently, we have enough flexible seating for four students along with carpet squares. The stools that I'm requesting will help with my fidgety students who like to move while they work due to the wobbling ability of the stool. The comfy floor seat gives students who still want to sit in a traditional chair a more comfortable way of doing so while still completing their work on clipboards. We also do a lot of collaborative work and each of the groups need to spread out in order to have enough space to work cooperatively. The soft seats will allow the groups who are on the floor a space to complete their group work. All of the items will work wonderfully to give the students a comfortable spot while reading independently. I want to give the opportunity of a comfortable work space to more of my students. They deserve it!
needStatement: My students need flexible seating to match the level of constant movement in both their bodies and their minds!

name: Seating to Keep the Wiggles Away!
description: My students walk into our classroom every day full of life, ready to learn, and excited for what is in store for them that day. I teach at a Title I school in North Carolina where 100 percent of our students receive free breakfast and lunch. Many of my students receive backpack food on the weekend. Quiet a few need to visit our district's clothing closet, just to be able to come to school in appropriate clothing. There have been a few who aren't sure where home will be at the end of the day. Despite so many hardships, my students are eager to learn and do their best. They want to be in school because they want to learn all they can so they can be successful one day. The bean bag chairs, yoga balls, wobble seats and portable desk will help my students who find it impossible to sit quietly and listen or complete independent work. These materials will not directly teach my students new skills, but they will help prime my students for learning in all content areas. For example, while I'm teaching a math lesson my students who usually are unable to sit still and quiet can use the wobble seat to help keep them selves focused while getting out their bottled up energy without being an interruption to others . The donations for this project will improve my classroom by reducing the amount of behavioral issues, because I will be able to provide the appropriate stimulation that my students need. With less behavioral issues, we can increase our learning and time on task. I'm looking forward to seeing my students happier and ready to learn.
needStatement: My students need alternatives to sitting at a traditional desk with wobble chairs, lap trays, and bean bag chairs. Alternative seating will help my students who need to move and wiggle to stay focused and on task.

name: Student Choice
description: Mexican, Salvadorian, Guatemalan, Colombiano, Japanese, these are a few of the cultures my students bring to our school. My students are eager to learn, excited to be at school, but also have faced many hardships at such a young age. I teach at a title 1 school, where 85% of our students qualify for free and reduce lunch. For some students, the school is the only safe place for them. I try to provide a safe place where learning is fun! These materials will be used to give options for student for working in the classroom. Many of my students work best when standing up or sitting on the floor. Standing desks, stability balls, and floor cushions will provide options for my students to learn the best way they can! Research has shown that students need to be given options for seating. Not all students learn best when sitting at your 'typical desk' but learn better and can focus more when standing up or sitting on the floor. I hope that by providing options for them, they will be more successful!
needStatement: My students need flexible seating in order to be successful on their academics. By providing options and spaces for them to sit at, it will increase the chances for them to be successful!

name: Wild About Learning and Reading!
description: My students are from an inner-city public school that is Title 1 and are predominantly Hispanic students. I have many students who are from foster care parents and/or 1 parent families. My students and parents care about their education and we all work together to make their student's education a positive experience. My students love to do hands-on projects and get up moving out of their seats! I want to do more community building activities and want this to become a daily part of our classroom routine. I think when students feel safe, valued, and know that learning can be fun; then, students feel empowered and know they can achieve anything!This rug will make a huge difference for my students as we love to get up out of our seats and do movement activities as well as all sit together to do community building time. My students currently have to sit on really old linoleum tile that is usually not the cleanest in our room. This rug will make it so much easier to get on the floor and do some cool hands-on projects as well allow for a clean and comfortable place for reading! My students become my family during the school year and I want to make them feel safe and have a fun and comfortable area to go for our class to have carpet time! I plan on incorporating community building projects to help foster my relationships with my students so they know that everyone in our class has a purpose and is cared and valued by everyone!!
needStatement: My students need this rug for our interactive time while we do hands-on activities, doing community activities, reading with a partner, or me reading to my class!

name: Teaching Tolerance Through Flexible Seating Choices (Part 2)
description: Every morning, my sweet students come to me from low-income to mid-income neighborhoods. Some are hungry. Some are tired. And, some just want a hug. Home life can be stressful, but at school, they can look forward to learning, friendships, food, and plenty of encouragement. For some of my students, our classroom is the one place they can count on for routine, safety, and community. Let's work together to bring these sweet students some joy in their education by creating a safe place for them to be innovative, creative, and think outside of the box!I am requesting several different choices of seating arrangements for the students in my Writing and Social Studies classroom in order to meet their physical needs. I would love to do away with standard school chairs and replace them with ways for my students to get their bodies and minds moving such as bouncy bands and stools. Every child in my classroom has different physical needs, and I desire to create an environment of acceptance and tolerance through flexible seating. Whether it's a case of the wiggles or an itch to move, my students would greatly benefit from stools, a computer chair, a bench, and bouncy bands. For the past five years of my teaching career, I have seen kids 'eye' other students who have to stand during class or need to go on a quick walk to move around. I have heard comments made under their breaths about the differences in how students work. This was made possible by having conventional desks and chairs where any slight difference for one or two students is very noticeable. This cannot continue. I have to change my classroom environment. I would love to help students understand that everyone has different physical needs, and that is totally okay! Over the past few months I have been collecting exercise balls, standing desks, and bicycle peddlers in an attempt to create an accepting environment. But, I still need more supplies to make this dream come true! I am asking for your help in creating a classroom where everyone is able to learn in their own way. I am asking for your help in creating a classroom where students can feel safe, comfortable, and normal. I am asking for your help in creating a classroom of tolerance. Thank you!
needStatement: My students need a computer chair, a bench, bouncy bands, and a stool to meet physical needs and help teach tolerance of differences between peers.

name: Help Us Start the Year Out Right With New Supplies!
description: Do you remember going school supply shopping? The excitement of a new year, picking out the perfect notebook and the cool pencil case? For many of my students, this is not a reality. Many of my students come to school with no school supplies. We are a community of thirty 4th Grade Scholars in a Title I school in Oregon. We are excited and eager to learn. Our school population is 100% free and reduced-price lunch. With shrinking school budgets it is getting harder and harder to provide students with the basic school supplies that are needed to learn. My students will be using these materials daily, they do not always get new materials so having new and unused materials to start out the year will be amazing! Markers, crayons, colored pencils, pencils, erasers, oil pastels, paint brushes, mini stamp markers, graph paper and glue are essential supplies to any classroom. These supplies will be used in every aspect of the classroom. My students will use these materials during math, reading, writing, art and so many other areas throughout the year. Every student deserves to have the basic supplies to help them achieve their full potential. By supporting this project you are giving my students what they need to have a successful 4th-grade year.
needStatement: My students need pencils, markers, crayons and other supplies to help them have a successful school year.

name: Mapping With Ozobots
description: In August, I will begin my 21st year in education. It is a blessing to spend my days at this beautiful community school in the spectacular mountains of western North Carolina. My drive to work is full of beautiful landscapes. My school is small (kindergarten through fifth grade), with fewer than 150 students. We may be small, but our dreams are big. The community is deeply invested in the education and the nurturing of each student. Economic status does not provide a barrier to learning, instead, it provides a challenge this school accepts on a daily basis. With your help, we can give these deserving students everything they need!Ozobot Bit is the world’s smallest smart robot. This right brain – left brain integrating bot builds both creativity and coding skills in children. It is my plan to have my students advance from basic color coding to intermediate block-based programming with Bit. Students can draw lines with the special markers, create obstacles and create color codes to control the Ozobots. This project is inspired by a project previously created by Ms. Mundt. Students will use the markers and chart paper to create a map of North Carolina. They will design the map so that at in each section like the Piedmont or Mountains the Ozobot will follow a code and spin or rapidly flash its lights. Fourth grade students will need to create their path so the Ozobot turns at the appropriate times and makes its way from one section of the map to the next.
needStatement: My students need an Ozobot dual pack with markers and unruled chart paper.

name: Morning Tubs: A Way to Promote Creativity and Social Skills
description: My students come from very diverse backgrounds. Close to 70% of my students live below the Federal Poverty Level. When my 1st grade students walk into my classroom I strive to provide for them an inviting, caring, and exciting learning experience. With so many personalities and such diverse home lives it can be difficult to make the transition to a learning environment. Yet once they are comfortable, they can work at something that seemed so difficult to them at first and then it happens...they get it! Now they are motivated to work hard and learn more. There is nothing more rewarding than the look of accomplishment on a 1st grade child's face. Each day after coming into the classroom my students put their belongings in their cubbies, have breakfast, and complete a morning warm up activity. After the activity is completed they are able to work with a Morning Tub. Morning Tubs allow students to work together while learning. My students need to learn how to interact with each other...many are very good at individual activities, but they need to learn how to share materials and ideas. Morning Tubs are a big part of this process. Each tub has materials inside that promote student socialization, collaboration, and creative learning. Morning Tubs offer a play-based opportunity for students to explore, create, and communicate. My class is divided into four groups (red, yellow, green, and blue), the morning tubs have a color code on the front. Each week I switch out the tubs so everyone gets a turn at each activity. The materials I requested will enhance student learning and build social skills as they work together on different activities. Rory’s Story Cubes have pictures with different themes like verbs, ways to move, places to visit. The students will roll 2-3 of the cubes and using the pictures along with their imagination they will combine them into a story. The Magna-Tiles are sized just right for little hands and easy to use to create a design on a flat surface or building in 3-D. Magna-Tiles develops patterning, shape recognition, building, and motor skills. The WonderFoam Dominos will be used for number tile matching games, sorting, counting, addition, and subtraction practice. I think the AGARE Brain Flakes will be a favorite. This is a set of interlocking snowflake shaped plastic disks. Students can build and learn. My students are excited about starting their day with these activities. They really love Morning Tubs!
needStatement: My students need materials to fill our morning tubs like Brain Flakes, Legos, and Magna-Tiles to promote student interaction and creativity.

name: Reading is Resistance!
description: My students are awesome! These Pre-K through eighth grade students come from a culturally rich community in the heart of central Portland. What makes this school so special is that many families have been apart of this school community for generations which means our school holds special meaning in the lives of these families. Our school is a Mandarin immersion school that also includes African Dance, international baccalaureate, right brain initiative (art), and rich cultural diversity. We have great community supports and partnerships as well. In our classroom, we have 23 students who weave a colorful fabric of different languages, racial and economic diversity, as well as athletic and artistic talents. My students bring to the classroom a wealth of cultural, linguistic, racial, religious, socioeconomic and academic differences. It is therefor important for these students to not only be able to identify with characters in the books they are reading but expose themselves to the differences in others. I want to empower my students with knowledge as well as compassion and advocacy for others. By providing socially and culturally diverse literature at varied levels, a wide range of students will be able to access the material and ideally find a number of different books that meet them at their reading level and also challenge them appropriately.
needStatement: My students need a variety of leveled books that represent not only themselves but others.

name: Literacy Liberty
description: The United States has been called, 'The Land of Opportunity.' Most citizens can describe the traditional 'American Dream' as the right and ability to carve out any life you choose. Unfortunately, for children, not all opportunities are equal. My students are the picture of America. They come from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds and vastly varied, socioeconomic lifestyles. Each child comes with their own life experiences, strengths, and weaknesses. They all want to feel safe and successful, and every one of them brings the need and desire to be loved. My students are curious, humorous, and zealous. They enjoy learning with their eyes, ears, and hands. As a classroom family, students work together, learn from each other, and strive for personal goals of personal best. Often times, students believe that reading is restricted to books. This can be overwhelming for students who lack confidence. This project will bring a bit of liberty to the classroom. Reading is reading. Building literacy requires more than an accomplished list of book titles. When time, stamina, or even interest is limited, many students simply choose not to read. My hope is that adding a fresh supply of kid friendly magazines will remove some of that pressure. Perhaps a novel full of chapters seems too daunting. Start with an article! Maybe sports heroes are more motivational that fantasy characters! So they can read Sports Illustrated Kids. Why not start your animal research with some fun facts from a sidebar in Zoobooks? The goal, at any age is to inspire a love of learning in my students. Instead of imposing restrictions, I hope to open young minds by offering choices and the freedom to make them.
needStatement: My students need kid friendly magazine options for their classroom library.

name: Run Run as Fast as You Can!
description: My students are amazing! We are a two time National School of Character and our students exhibit this every day. Our students lead assemblies, have classroom jobs and leadership roles. They love to learn and connect their learning to the real world. We like to make learning hands-on and fun! We are dedicated to finding new ways to get my kids excited about learning. I know that creating lifelong learners is a huge part of my job. By making learning FUN, I can foster a love of learning in my young students. These resources will help my students become better runners. We have to get ready for our track meet, and these materials will get them running. The cones and mats will be used to create starting points and obstacles. The balls will be used to create a variety of games to get them moving. The chalk will be used to write times, and create more running games on pavement. My kids love to move! I know these materials will get our team up and moving, which will make us faster and better riunners. The variety will allow us to get creative with our activities and keep kiddos excited for practice. I can't wait to get them started and to see how we do in our final competition.
needStatement: My students need spot markers, balls, and cones for running training.

name: Resistance and Redemption: Unraveling The 'March' Trilogy
description: We are a very small school: 100 students. The reason DCS is so small is because we are, in essence, a modern-day, one-room schoolhouse. Our students are taught every subject in mixed-grade classes. We find, with the right amount of differentiating the material for the older and younger students, the students mentor one another, find role models, observe what struggle and humility look like. Our students are on a constant search to nurture and satisfy their sense of intellectual curiosity. To them and their families, education is the first priority in life. Because of the economic hardships many of our families face, they understand the connection between receiving a high-quality education and achieving success in life. We consider our school's curriculum to be extremely rigorous, and our expectations of our students are high. Our school represents the rich ethnic and racial spectrum of the city of Newark. Our students and staff are African-American, Caribbean, Caucasian, Hispanic and Middle Eastern: Muslim, Protestant, Jewish and Catholic. There are students whose families have been in Newark for decades, and students whose families have just arrived here from abroad: all-in-all our school community represents over 30 countries from around the world.DCS kicks off the coming school year with a school-wide, interdisciplinary unit of study on our city: Newark, NJ. The title of the unit is 'Newark: Revolution, Rebellion and Rebirth'. One of the periods we will focus on in-depth is the Newark Riots of 1967, also known as the Newark Rebellion. I am seeking literature to teach in English Language Arts which will enrich the students' knowledge of that period in American history, specifically as it relates to the African-American's struggle for civil rights in the 1960s. The 'March' Trilogy is a perfect vehicle to teach my students one man's real-life account of social rebellion in the 1960s, written in a format to which they can relate easily. 'March' is a graphic novel, presented in three parts, the story of the life of Rep. John Lewis. The format of a graphic novel will gain critical buy-in from my students and give them an immediate feeling that the material is in an accessible format. The use of 'comic book' conventions, will naturally convey the urgency and drama of the events. I am positive that the combination of the powerful content of John Lewis' story and the inviting design of the graphic novel will give my students a vivid context through which to view what happened in Newark in July of 1967: how it could happen in America and why it had to happen.
needStatement: My students need to study the 'March' trilogy, so they may analyze the trajectory of a life steeped in the social activism and racial turmoil of 1960s America.

name: Let's Find Out:Tolerance in The Classroom
description: My students and I are part of this wonderful Title I school. We are a very diverse school with many different backgrounds in one. Many students come in not speaking any English and some parents require translators to communicate. Our goal here is to meet the needs of our students. To assist us in meeting these needs, we provide classes for parents to teach them the English language. In September, my children will enter eager yet unsure of what to expect. I will be there to assure them each day that the year will be fun. Each day will be different from the day before, but each day incredibly inspiring as we learn and grow together! These children will make me smile just as much as I make them laugh. I love what I do and look forward to providing them with many opportunities to succeed in the future. My goal is to help my superstars succeed!My children need different seating options to promote tolerance and acceptance of different learning styles. We currently have some Hokki Stools but the addition of these cushions will help build attention for my young learners. I want to create a classroom where everyone can learn in their own way and feel safe and comfortable while doing it. Whether it's a case of the wiggles or an itch to move, my students would greatly benefit from this seating option as they learn and grow with one another. My children also need to learn about the world around them. Holidays, cultures and traditions are briefly touched upon in our current Social Studies program. As a teacher I feel it is very important to teach children to connect to the world as well as others around them. My children need to learn that not everyone celebrates, eats and acts the same way and that is ok. With the help of Scholastic's Let's Find Out magazine subscription each child will have a year worth of nonfiction articles that will enable me to supplement and extent topics in our current program. Children will make connections, ask questions and discuss many topics in detail. It is my hope is that I can help build tolerance within children beginning with my students! Remember they are MY students but OUR future!
needStatement: My students need a subscription of Let's Find Out magazines and wobbly cushions.

name: Subitizing! Number Sense! Addition and Subtraction Facts!
description: My 1st grade students are awesome! We are a caring community of learners who watch out for each other, encourage each other, and show compassion for each other. We are excited to learn about our world and love acquiring new knowledge about how we are connected with our environment. We have a growth mindset in class, which means we might not be able to do something yet, but that doesn't mean we will never be able to do it or learn it. We work like scholars by sticking to the task and having a thirst for knowledge. We spend a lot of time developing number sense in first grade. Having a class set of sturdy Rekenraks will help my math lessons run more smoothly. In the past, I had the students make their own Rekenraks using cardboard, pipe cleaners, and red and white pony beads. However, they don't hold up very well because we use them a lot. I would have to stop the lesson to help a child put their handmade Rekenrak back together. It took precious time away from the lesson. Rekenraks will help my students develop the number sense they need to become fluent mathematicians. Rekenraks will help my students subitize, build a strong sense of 5 and 10, and learn about the relationships among numbers and operations. I know my students will benefit greatly by having a class set and for me a teacher demonstration Rekenrak.
needStatement: My students need a class set of Rekenreks to build their number sense and learn their addition and subtraction math facts.

name: Teaching Tolerance
description: My students are very energetic and love to do hands-on activities. They are very social and are still learning how to interact with their peers. My students love to learn through movement and play. Although my students differ in where they are with their educational needs, they are very supportive and push their peers to be the best they can be. As a class, we love learning together in fun and engaging ways. We love our Kindergarten family and all the fun things that we do! My students need fiction and nonfiction books focused around teaching tolerance. These books will help my students make text to text, text to self, and text to world connections. Through these books, my students can learn skills such as empathy, acceptance, patience and understanding. These books follow specific lessons that teach life long skills. The skills that they learn from these books will transfer into their everyday lives, teaching my students to be kind and caring to one another. With students putting themselves in other peoples shoes and learning tolerance, we can create a classroom built around empathy. We can treat others the way we want to be treated.
needStatement: My students need fiction and nonfiction books that teach them tolerance.

name: My Buddy and Me!
description: My students and I are part of this wonderful Title I school. We are a very diverse school with many different backgrounds in one. Many students come in not speaking any English and some parents require translators to communicate. Our goal here is to meet the needs of our students. To assist us in meeting these needs, we provide classes for parents to teach them the English language. In September, my children will enter eager yet unsure of what to expect. I will be there to assure them each day that the year will be fun. Each day will be different from the day before, but each day incredibly inspiring as we learn and grow together! These children will make me smile just as much as I make them laugh. I love what I do and look forward to providing them with many opportunities to succeed in the future. My goal is to help my superstars succeed!Part of teaching tolerance also includes helping my students learn social-emotional skills for regulating emotions and being sensitive to others, as well as building on friendships. This year I plan to do just that with the help of a buddy system. I plan to randomly pair up two children each week for them to get to know each other. They will spend time together as they eat lunch, have fun together during brain breaks and explore during center time. Weekly buddy pairs and pictures will be displayed in the requested pocket charts. With your help buddies can select from the requested center manipulatives to explore together. Buddies can choose from the Alphabet Rockets, Geostix, Gumball Grab, retelling kits and puppets, Snap and Slide math center or the Kinetic Sand Ice Cream center. Each day children will be given brain breaks and explore time where they will be able to share the above mentioned materials with their buddy. As they explore in centers they will learn about one another, share and build friendships. Building tolerance and acceptance of others as well as developing friendships are all important skills that my children will learn with my new weekly buddy system. Allowing children the time to get to know a friend will help establish healthy self-esteem, self-confidence all while teaching about tolerance and acceptance of all. I plan on doing this with by restocking our manipulative center. Remember they may be MY students but they are OUR future and teaching tolerance is an important skill all should learn.
needStatement: My students need story telling and big book activity kits with puppets, pocket charts and cards to display buddy for the week and center activities such as gumball grab, alphabet rockets and Geostix.

name: Light Up Our Learning!
description: My classroom is made up of 25 eager, energetic, hard-working, and awesome first graders. I have an inclusion class where there are a variety of needs, learning styles, and developmental levels of the students. They come from many different backgrounds, where many of them have had difficult obstacles to overcome already at an early age in their life. Several of them really lack the confidence needed to work toward their full potential. Many of them find it incredibly challenging to focus and pay attention throughout the entire school day. Our school is a Title I school and has a large low-socioeconomic population, which means there is a large percentage of students receiving free and reduced lunch. Some of them do not always come to school with the things they need to help them be successful.A light table is a great teaching tool and can help students learn in a cooperative way. My first grade inclusion classroom is a very active and busy place of learning. A light table will help capture students' attention and help them drive their enthusiasm toward learning. The light table will be a great resource for teaching science and discovery. It can also be used to help students get excited about literacy and math. Students can use a light table to look at numbers and letters. They will be able to build words, solve addition and subtraction problems, and build structures. The letters, numbers, and accessory kit will be used for daily center stations focused on literacy and math. The tongs will help to strengthen their fine motor skills by encouraging them to maneuver their materials in a more challenging method. These materials will allow my students hands-on experiences with manipulatives in a new and exciting environment. A light table in my classroom will help students work together in a cooperative way. Working together and learning through interactions is a big part of first grade. A light table in my class will make all the difference.
needStatement: My students need a portable light table and light table accessories to encourage hands-on learning.

name: Play, Learn and Grow Together
description: For many Pre-Kindergarten students, this is their first experience with school. Many students struggle with social skills and physical motor skills both large and small. Many of my students do not get quality experiences with quality sports equipment. Pre-K students need to have ample time, space and equipment to learn and grow. I teach in a school where 100% of our students receive free breakfast and lunch. Students at my school look forward to physical education to learn skills to play different sports. They enjoy practicing new skills and engaging in friendly competition with their classmates. Young children are less likely to take part in extracurricular team sport than their older peers. I believe it is very important to encourage young children to get involved in extracurricular team sports. There are many sports my students are interested in such as basketball, soccer, and golf. Team sports are very important for shaping personalities. It's important that kids understand the mentality behind playing team sports and playing for one another and playing with friends.— Brian O'Driscoll I will be setting up extracurricular sports teams for my young students. With these materials, the young children can try a variety of sports. I will be setting up extracurricular teams in the areas of: golf, basketball, and soccer. These extracurricular sports teams will expose my young learners to team sports. By playing on extracurricular teams my students will learn crucial skills in many different sports. These experiences will impact them throughout their lives, such as when it comes to working professionally, respecting authority figures and also respecting their peers. With the help of these extracurricular sports teams, my young learners are going to become team players and learn many new skills. Donations to this project will allow the younger students in my school to build important life skills such as teamwork, confidence, and sportsmanship. Thank You!
needStatement: My students need basketballs, basketball goal, soccer balls, soccer goals, soft skin soft balls, and golf sets, .

name: Simple Supplies: Dry Erase Markers and Glue Sticks
description: My students are between the ages of 5 and 6. My students are ready to learn each day. My school is located in one of the highest poverty areas. When at school, they get to feel safe and escape from wondering where their next meal is coming from. My school is a Title I school that provides free breakfast and lunch. Students know they are safe and taken care of while in our care. My student love to come to school each day. I seek to give my students a safe place to express themselves.I am requesting basic classroom supplies to ensure that my students' learning needs are met! We are in need of dry erase markers and glue sticks. We use these items every single day. As you can guess, in a kindergarten classroom we go through a lot of dry erase markers and glue sticks. These items will be used in our everyday learning. We use dry erase markers in our literacy lesson. They learn to write their letters and recognize them. We use glue sticks in too many activities to list. Both of these items help my little kindergartners' fine motor skills. Your donation will be greatly appreciated and used daily.
needStatement: My students need dry erase markers and glue sticks. We are constantly running out of dry erase markers and glue sticks. We use these items every day. We could really use these in our classroom.

name: 'Block Heads'
description: I teach in an arts magnet school that has a diverse population of students including low, middle and upper middle class families. Because I teach Transitional Kindergarten, my students come to me from all over our school district and are given a chance to experience Core Curriculum through instruction in visual and performing arts, culinary arts, music, drama, movement, and dance. Their creative, original work is shared all over campus, and each trimester at 'Presentation Nights.' One of the most beautiful elements on our campus is the incorporation of special needs students into our arts programs. Even though my students start school as four-year-olds, they quickly become responsible caring students and are encouraged to be collaborative learners. I am proud of the way my students embrace their classmates with special needs and treat them with respect and dignity. My project, 'Block Heads' is fueled by my belief that, when given interesting resources, students are inspired to problem solve. The simplicity of building blocks provokes the imagination of children. In order to build what they imagine, students have to figure things out, work together, and fail until they succeed. I have watched my students use the few blocks we have to create skyscrapers, airports, race tracks, homes, castles, parking garages, ramps, towers, train stations, and even a zoo! Block building has been a powerful motivator for my bilingual students to learn to communicate with their peers, and it has allowed my special needs students to play successfully alongside their classmates. The most significant work the children do as they play, is learn to share ideas, and collaborate to complete their vision. Even students with limited vocabulary can communicate ideas, and participate in block play. My current wooden block collection is small, so only a small group of children can play with them. I would love to see many small groups using blocks to build toward a common goal. For example, if one group is building an airport, another group might build a parking garage or restaurant that would support the airport. Blocks can compliment any curriculum theme. I believe that vocabulary is a predictor of academic success. If a child can imagine it, build it, and talk about it, later that same child will be able to write about it, and share reasons for his or her own ideas and experiences. I love the statement, 'good writing is good thinking.' It is my belief, that by creating a classroom full of 'Block Heads', my students will think better, and in time, they will be able to write better, calculate better, reason better, and create better. Be a 'Block Head'.
needStatement: My students need good old fashioned wooden building blocks to build vocabulary and foster cooperation, collaboration and creativity.

name: A Comfortable Place to Learn!
description: Our Elementary school is a small Title 1 school in California. We serve a large immigrant community, and most of our families have limited means. They simply are not able to donate the extra funds found in more affluent schools. My class is one of three special education classrooms serving children wit intellectual disabilities and autism. When you walk into my classroom you see space filled with 'left-overs'. There are chairs with cracked seats and missing slides, a mish-mash of other furniture, desks of all sizes in similar condition. It is simply an uncomfortable environment to learn in. My students deserve better. My students have special needs. It is more important than ever that they have safe, comfortable chairs to sit in in order to focus and learn. Currently, my classroom is furnished with left-overs. Some of the chairs have cracked seats and missing slides. They are made from various materials and are various sizes (some which don't fit the desks we use). There is not enough seating to allow for mainstreaming with other classes. Now, imagine a comfortably furnished classroom with enough seating for 15 to 20 students. These chairs will improve the environmental conditions in which my students learn and provide enough seating for non-disabled peers to join us for special projects and social skills.
needStatement: My students need safe, comfortable chairs to sit in in order to be able to focus and learn.

name: Supplies and Organization
description: My students are from a low income community. Our school district recently lost over $30 million in budget cuts. Our students are needing some extra love from the DonorsChoose.org community! My students love being active both inside and outside the classroom, and I often find myself stumbling to keep up with them. We have a large English Language Learner community as well as a large SPED department at our school. My students require multiple ways to keep active while still learning. In third grade, students have to pass the Reading test to pass the grade. I'm wanting a way to organize the books by reading levels. This will allow my students to find the books within their reading level quickly and easily. With nicely labeled book bins, there will be no guessing for my students if they have the correct book for their level or not. I also need a stapler to staple my students' papers together and to hang things up on our bulletin boards. Tape will allow students to tape their papers back together when they tear their papers. The pens will give me something to grade papers with.
needStatement: My students need basic organization for books, tape for torn papers, and staples to hang up their work on the bulletin board.

name: Keeping it Clean in Kindergarten
description: My students are enthusiastic children who are ready to learn. They love to explore and answer questions about the world around them. They are great at helping each other and understanding each other's differences. They are some of the hardest workers I have seen. They never tell me they can't do something, just that they will try their best. They know that as long as they try their best they can reach their goals! They even encourage me to try my best on a daily basis. My students' have a real passion for learning and many parents and students tell me that their students favorite place to be is school. Unfortunately, if my students get sick they can not focus at school and many times they can not come at all. This causes them to miss out on their learning. It can also mean they miss meals and a safe place to be during the day. If my students were to have cleaning supplies in the classroom to keep them healthy, they would be able to reap the benefits of school more consistently. My students would be able to learn more from me and each other. School during flu season wouldn't feel like a constant game of catch up with 5-6 kids out everyday. The biggest benefit of the tissues, disinfecting wipes, hand sanitizer and disinfecting spray is the kids being healthier. Healthier kids mean kids that are happier and productive members of their social groups. That is what I want for all my kids to be. Happy and and successful.
needStatement: My students need tissues, disinfecting wipes, hand sanitizer and disinfecting spray.

name: Flexible Seating in 3rd Grade!
description: My class is a very energetic and curious bunch! They are always wanting to learn more about every subject. They fuel one another's eagerness to continue learning and want more from every lesson. You can see their minds crave more as they learn in every subject. They keep our classroom engaging and my job fun. They also have a great bond with one another, they truly treat one another like family. It's an awesome group to work with everyday. They create a warm and welcoming classroom. Every student has a typical work space in my classroom; a desk and a chair. However, sometimes they work better when they are allowed to choose their seats around the room. I have a small sofa and camping chairs that they use clipboards at, and it always is a relaxing alternative work space for them. I would love to add this set of table and chairs! It would be a great space for students to get a break from their 'same old desk,' and get them excited about staying on task, just by having a different perspective of their work space. It is large enough that a pair of students can work on a project together as well.
needStatement: My students need flexible seating to get a break from always sitting at their desks.

name: Handy Sacks for Learning!
description: The students in my class are an inquisitive bunch. They explore everything around them, any chance they get. The students come from many different backgrounds. Some students are new to the country and are learning English now. Some student's families are single parent households, which make it difficult for both student and parent, as they face many challenges. The neighborhood around the school consists of mostly single family homes. There are, however, many apartment homes being built which will bring more children to our school. If my students have easy access to the materials they need to do their work for the day, they will have more time on tasks and less time wasted looking for what they need. The seat sacks will allow them to keep the most used items within reach. It will help them build organizational skills as well as making them accountable for their own materials. Many students haven't learned the importance of having their school books and materials in a special place. This goes along with teaching responsibility and good study habits. They should all have a place that allows them to complete school work.
needStatement: My students need seat sacks to keep the materials they need for the day within reach.

name: Getting Those Creative Juices Flowing With STEM Bins!
description: Our school of approximately 540 students is part of an excellent school district. However, we have a higher percentage of low-income families than the rest of the district. This creates additional challenges that are not present at the other schools. Our school does an excellent job of providing opportunities for all students to learn and experience success. My first graders are passionate, inquisitive, and energetic. They love when they get to do hands-on activities such as math and Daily 5 centers. They would be so excited to start their day with STEM Bins!I want my students to walk in the door and be excited to start the day! Traditionally, students usually unpack, do their lunch count, and then get started on a worksheet known as 'morning work.' Teachers need this time to speak with individual students, take attendance, read parent notes, and more. We also cannot start our first lesson until after school announcements are finished. Instead of a worksheet, I would love to give students the opportunity to create and collaborate with peers using STEM Bins. These bins would contain materials to design and create various tasks. Students could create a simple machine using wheels, levers, and pulleys, test the effects of different inclined planes, or discover how gears work by combining different sizes together. They could also build simple 3D shapes or try to build real-world objects such as a skyscraper. The sky is the limit! Using STEM Bins would begin the students' day on a positive note, enhance socialization skills, and build confidence with problem-solving skills. It would also help develop a love for the engineering design process at an early age. My students are only 6 and 7 years old, but we expect so much from them throughout the entire day. These STEM bins would be a great bridge between allowing a little bit of play while still developing important skills.
needStatement: My students need engaging, hands-on materials to start their day with STEM bins!

name: Bringing the Outside/Inside
description: We are the Duck classroom and as it is with Ducks and ducklings we are a team of active, curious and creative people. As you know the mama duck leads the ducklings into exciting and new adventures; she is patient and waits for them to overcome their obstacles. Just as it is in our class of EC/SPED children, which come from lower economic backgrounds, we constantly offer them new adventures that challenges their thinking and allow them to tackle the obstacles that can halt their learning. Through relationships with adults, play, and planned and spontaneous instruction, our children will grow and develop skills needed for the future. Summer or early Fall is a great time for camping out under the stars, snuggling up in sleeping bags, roasting marshmallows and singing and telling stories over a campfire, but for the children in my classroom most of them have never experienced camping. With this project, bringing the camping experience inside for children who have never been camping will provide them with hands on comprehension of the experience. By designing a lesson which will Include activities and games that develop literacy, increase vocabulary, teach math concepts, and the enjoyment learning what happens in nature. The goal is to integrate each center with the requested items, such as the math center will house the counting insects, science; Kangaroo's Insect Bug Adventure Set; there will be the requested books in the library area. The water table will have the Eagle Claw Snap-On Floats Assortment and in the dramatic play area I will use the tents, sleeping bags camping chair and more. Children will count, problem solve, listen, match, sing, role play, move, exercise, and more! So, when the opportunity arises for the children that I serve to go camping they will be able to share what they have learned with their families.
needStatement: My students need books, camping dramatic play toys, puzzles, camping decor, water table toys, and play insects.

name: Wooden Blocks Play Center
description: At our school, our students are a very diverse, multi-lingual group of children. Many of our students are first or second generation immigrants. The children come to us from a variety of different socioeconomic and cultural backgrounds. Last year, I taught first grade and in the fall, I will be teaching Kindergarten. (The photo I have posted is from last year's class, as I have not met my class for next year yet.) My students are Kindergarteners. For some it will be their first experience with school, and I am looking forward to creating a warm and nurturing learning community for them! They will be 4 and 5 year-olds. They will be a community of curious, energetic, individual and unique children eager to make friends and learn new things! I'm so excited to meet my students in the fall!These wooden blocks will be a part of a play center in our classroom. Building with wooden blocks helps children develop fine motor skills, learn to be creative, problem-solve, work with others and nurtures a multitude of other skills! Play centers are also important for oral-language building skills, for instance, when children present their creations to the class and/or ask and answer questions about them.I believe play is very important for a Kindergartener's healthy holistic development. After recently reading the book Purposeful Play by Kristine Mraz, I learned about how all the different types of play are important for children in different ways. I think the addition of wooden blocks will provide my Kindergarteners with a greater variety of play experiences.
needStatement: My students need wooden building blocks for creative play in our Kindergarten classroom.

name: Back To School Supplies
description: I teach at a Title I school in North Carolina where 100 percent of our students receive free breakfast and lunch. Despite the many challenges they face, my third graders walk into our classroom every day full of life and ready to learn. The sky is the limit in our classroom. I feel lucky to be their teacher each and everyday. I may not be able to control their home lives; however, I can certainly control their experience during the school day. My students need sturdy book bins! Sturdy book bins will help students clearly see all of their book choices when book shopping. This will also make it easier for students to learn organizational skills as they will be able to put our books back into the correct place. Both items will help our classroom by putting these materials in reach of the students. My students also need a mini-refrigerator. A mini-fridge will be used to store snacks for students and for science projects in which we need to show changes in states of matter. Having the mini-fridge in the classroom will make these projects more accessible and observable for the class.
needStatement: My students need sturdy book bins for our classroom library. We also need a mini-fridge to keep cold snacks, popsicles, and even to use with science projects!

name: Comfortable Lighting, Soothing Sounds And Alternative Seating For Happy Students
description: A typical day in my classroom starts 30 minutes before the first bell. My students trickle in and quickly start working on mastering addition and subtraction facts on their iPads. There are lots of cheers and celebrating as students reach individual milestones in their learning. It's an awesome way to start the day. Welcome to my class, where laughter and learning go hand in hand!This has been my classroom motto for the last 19 years. My students are having so much fun they don't even realize they are learning too! I teach a group of wonderful First Graders! They show such a happiness and eagerness to learn but they have to overcome so many obstacles. We are a Title I school. More than 95% of our students are on the free lunch program. I am often the one providing my students the materials and supplies they need to be successful in the classroom. Despite the obstacles they face, they come to school each morning with a smile and a curiosity to learn. My passion is teaching my young students how to be successful, life-long learners. The sky's the limit!I am trying to provide my students with the most comfortable learning environment I can. In addition to numerous seating options, I want to change the physical environment as well. I hope to accomplish this through lights and sounds. My goal is to mask the harsh florescent lights with soothing blue light covers. Research has shown that florescent lighting can cause anxiety and other behavioral issues, as well as health issues such as migraine headaches. Additionally, the sound machine will allow students to remain focused despite the many noises in and around our classroom. The lap trays will be used by students who chose not to sit in the traditional student desks. Comfortable children= happy, productive learners.
needStatement: My students need light covers, a sound machine, and adjustable lap tables.

name: Unite With Coding
description: My scholars are 32 energetic sixth-grade GATE students. They are a group that is about to embark on a new journey into middle school. They are a passionate, kind, and resilient bunch that perseveres even through difficult situations. They are eager to learn and have recently found their own voice in an effort to speak up against social injustices. This year, they have strengthened their technological abilities and are learning to integrate new components of media into presentations and projects. My school has started an arts program that teaches students dance, singing, art, computer programming, and various musical instruments both throughout the day and after school. My scholars are now ready to become more creative with their art skills. While the students are excited to learn the new programming elements, they are held back due to the fact that they don't have the necessary tools to take their progress to the next level. Spheros are fun, interactive robots that students can control and code. I am proposing to use this tool to teach my students about different elements of art while infusing instruction with 21st century learning skills. By introducing these ideas in this way, students will let their guard down and work with others that they don't generally choose to work with. The focus will be on the task at hand, and not who they are working with. Students will create coding that will be programmed into these robots. From there, the Spheros will navigate according to their code through different stations of paint, creating abstract art. Since my students are interested in technology and art, this will be what drives them and motivates them to work with others to be successful. Students will work together to problem solve as they try new approaches to achieve their end goal. With this project, students will be able to create art in a new way, and learn how to work with others as they become more accepting of their differences.
needStatement: My students need a Sphero robot to explore the elements of abstract art and coding as they learn to work with each other and build tolerance and acceptance.

name: Student's Passion for Reading
description: This Elementary school is an extraordinary school because of its diversity. Each student's brings something unique to the classroom. At this school there are 21 languages spoken and 38% of the students are english language learners. The school is a Title 1 school located in Portland, Oregon. The demographics of the school is 46% Black/African American, 25% Hispanic Latino, 10% Multi Racial, and 15% White. The diversity of the school creates an environment where students are being prepared to be successful in our diverse world. The books that I am asking for will be used to develop a passion for reading. Thank you for considering this proposal. The guided reading books that I am asking for will be used to develop a passion for reading. The books will be used in the classroom, small groups, independent reading time and be taken home. Having a library full of books for students to choose from will create an opportunity for students to be prepared for their futures. The books will be used in third through fifth grade and be used in nine different classrooms. These books will also be used in a before school reading program were older students read to younger students. Students who participate in the before school program will receive some of these books to take home and keep.
needStatement: My students need these books to create their own library at home to nourish their passion for reading.

name: New Materials For a New Year!
description: My students are 4th and 5th graders with a variety of special needs! They are kind and loving kids who need extra help in reading, writing and math. Unfortunately, we live in an area with a high poverty rate so many of the student's parents are not able to provide the supplies we need to enrich students' learning. Students with special needs have to try harder than their peers each day in order to catch up to their grade level peers. With better and more engaging materials, I can help peak their interest to help them learn!These materials will be used as exciting new resources to kick off the new school year. My students get so excited and motivated to use new resources from donor's choose. The dividers I have requested will play an important role in gaining the attention of my students with attention deficits. We need chart paper to create anchor charts that will help students learn new concepts and refer back to them throughout the year. I have requested two separate math resources that will be a great addition to my small group instruction! The clocks will be important in helping my students gain life skills like telling time. The Pick a Problem set will be a great word problem warm-up for each of my students.
needStatement: My students need math and classroom supplies to kick off the new school year! We need math start stories, math warm-up problems and a chart tablet.

name: Chill out in Pre-K!
description: I teach in a young 5's classroom and I have a diverse classroom of students from several countries including India, Russia, and Laos. I have seven students who are in the English Language learning program in our school. Many of my students are part of an English-speaking school for the first time. My students come from a variety of socio-economic backgrounds. My students are learning social, fine motor, mathematical and literacy skills that will help prepare them for their upcoming year in Kindergarten. We need a refrigerator in our classroom for perishable snacks and allergy needs in our classroom. The health and safety of my students are extremely important to me as their teacher and I want to provide a space for their dietary needs. Having this refrigerator would also cut down on time that students might typically spend on traveling to the office for three specific items, which frees up time for learning. I strive to meet the needs of my students and provide a learning environment where they feel comfortable and secure. Thank you for supporting my project, I appreciate your support!
needStatement: My students need a refrigerator in our classroom for perishable snacks and allergy concerns.

name: The Power of Mistakes: Creating a Risk Tolerant Classroom!
description: My students are part of the AVID program. Many of them are low-income, first generation, multi-lingual students. They come from all corners of the earth - South and Southeast Asia, Africa and South America. A wonderfully diverse group of high-energy, caring young people! A common dream unites my students - graduating from college. They have given up a 'fun' class in order to take the AVID elective, which prepares them for college success. My students of have overcome obstacles to be successful despite the fact that many of them are considered 'at-risk' Their greatest strength is their determination to be accepted to their college of choice. They are funny, clever and wonderful people to be around. I am so lucky and blessed to have them as my students. For this project, I am requesting Growth Mindset posters to reinforce the value of mistakes in the service of learning and specific games that help build community, tolerance and growth. 'A student with a growth mindset is likely to embrace challenges & persist in the face of setbacks'-Carol Dweck. Because we welcome new students throughout the year we have a real need to build community by getting to know our new students quickly. The games that I have listed are group activities that include questions which are posed in a safe, non-threatening manner that will help students to understand each other's values, thoughts and ideas on a variety of subjects. I am requesting 3 different types of conversations starters that range from the basic 'low-risk' questions to more thoughtful and personal questions. These will be used to start conversations, quick writes, build community and help the student increase their literacy and speaking skills. These activities will also nurture a risk-tolerant class culture by helping students connect through shared experiences as well as accepting each others' differences in opinions. The Growth Mindset posters will reinforce our lessons that success is obtained through grit, perseverance and determination.
needStatement: My students need fun and engaging ways to understand their strengths, to achieve their potential and build their classroom community.

name: Kindergarten Pirates In Search Of Treasures: Classroom Supplies and Storage
description: Students who are in this particular kindergarten class come from all different walks of life. It is not just a classroom full of students but it is a loving community built on support, trust, and respect. Children in this classroom have all different life styles and economic standings. Most of the students within this classroom are in foster care or struggle economically. These students have the biggest hearts, warmest smiles, and the most joyful giggles. Students come into class excited and ready to learn. They deserve a classroom that can empower them to be the best that they can be! We learn together, explore together, grow together, and inspire one another each and every day! By implementing flexible seating, like the wobble chair and balance ball, within my students’ classroom it will enable them to build a strong community and develop the best learning environment for their unique learning abilities. Not only will flexible seating allow for a safe and joyful learning environment but so will the additional storage units. By having a bookshelf to display featured books and shelving units to neatly organize necessary classroom materials it will create a friendly learning environment to encourage reading and peer connections. New writing materials like clipboards and dry erase boards will also encourage students' imaginations to set sail! It also helps facilitate a learning environment that empowers students to become authors, illustrators, scientists, mathematicians, explores, and dreamers.
needStatement: My students need the minimal necessities for setting up a classroom as well as flexible seating such as balance balls, wobble chairs, low teaching table, and clipboards to differentiate classroom instruction.

name: Wobbling, Moving and Learning!
description: My fourth grade students are an amazing group of students each and every year. They come to school ready to learn and grow their young minds. My students come from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds and there are many high risk students. Many of my students come to school hungry and don't have a home structure. My students know our classroom offers them a safe and nurturing environment where they can grow and expand their minds. Our classroom community is a place where students are safe, they learn and the learning field is the same for every student who enters our room. My students have difficulty sustaining attention for long periods of time. My classroom offers different work areas for individual students or groups to thrive. I know that Wobble Chairs at our Guided U Shape Table will help small groups of students focus while moving. Gentle movement forward, backward or side-to-side provides a calming effect that improves focus and encourages learning. Guided Reading, Writing and Math is a special time and place where I can work with small groups of students and give them extra support and feedback. They will be excited and focused with Wobble Chairs.I watch how my students learn best each and every year. They learn best with movement around the classroom. They are quite fidgety and need to move their bodies to maintain active minds. I know these chairs will enhance and excel small group learning for all of my students.
needStatement: My students need Classroom Select’s NeoRok Stool chairs for flexible seating. These are 'wobble' chairs that allow students to focus using movement.

name: Read to Succeed!
description: My students are coming to my classroom from all walks of life. It is my role as their teacher to meet them where they are. I want my students to feel secure and special the moment they walk through my door. It is said that students don't care how much you know until they know how much you care. Meeting the needs of all students is a challenging task, but one I take to heart. I want to provide an environment where all students will learn and reach their full potential. Reading and comprehending what is read is critical in today's world. Students need to be exposed to and have the opportunity to read good literature. The reading clips will help my students to dig deeper while they are reading. The bean bags will offer a comfortable place for students to enjoy reading a good book. Books can take you anywhere! I truly believe that there is some type of literature that every student can find that they will enjoy reading. As Dr. Seuss says, 'The more you read, the more you will know. The more you know, the more places you will go.' Watching my students while they are totally engrossed in a book is so rewarding.
needStatement: My students need to improve their comprehension. The clips will help the students to dig deeper while they are reading. I also want to provide a comfortable place for the students to read.

name: Think Outside the Block
description: My early learners (pre-k) come into my classroom eager to know more about the world around them. They represent a variety of social, cultural, and economic backgrounds, but all have one thing in common – a desire to learn. Upon entering my classroom, they are exposed to many opportunities to explore the world through structured and unstructured play. Through play, my students have the opportunity to develop their social skills through interacting with one another, practice and refine their understanding of language and number concepts, and learn to express themselves creatively. It is my goal, as their teacher, to foster a love of learning that they can carry forth into their elementary and secondary school years. Block play is recognized as a valuable tool in supporting the cognitive development of young learners. Block play can support children's emerging understandings of mathematical concepts, such as categorization, magnitude (bigger versus smaller), numbers, pattern & shape, spatial relations, and part-whole relationships. Given the benefits of block play I am requesting funds to purchase the following materials for use in my classroom: (a)Hardwood community vehicles set, (b) Lakeshore Community Garages, (c) Block play traffic signs, and (d) Block play home builder. I have several intended uses of these materials. First, the materials will be utilized by my students in the Block Play Center in my classroom, where they have opportunities to engage in (a) unstructured play and (b) teacher prompted activities involving constructive or dramatic play. Second, I will utilize thesematerials during the year when I provide direct small- and large-group instruction on the topics of Community Helpers and Transportation (both are units I cover), as well as mathematical concepts such as shape, size (absolute and relative), and number. Finally, I intend to use the blocks in the telling and re-telling of stories (which can be useful in fostering language and reading development).
needStatement: My students need additional materials for the block center so they have the opportunity to engage in block play.

name: The Future Is Flexible
description: As teachers, we must adapt with our students, in today’s society, to help our kids feel welcome in our classrooms. Outside the windows of our classroom is a dynamic, fast-paced, and ever-changing world full of choices. How can we expect our students to solve problems and make choices independently, if they are not in the environment they feel comfortable learning in? Our classroom settings should be conducive to open collaboration, communication, creativity, and critical thinking. I am involving my students in a classroom redesign project with the newest rave, flexible seating. Research has proven that physical activity is linked to higher academic performance, better health, more positive outlook and improved behavior. I, as an adult, have a hard time sitting still for 8 hours a day. When I have to sit in a conference all day, my mind wanders, so how do 10-year-old students feel? No matter what age range, all kids have a hard time sitting still. Because of this, I would like a classroom atmosphere where students choose their seating, just like you would hope for choices in seating at a restaurant or theater. I want my students to enjoy their classroom and be engaged. These materials will help students be comfortable when sitting in the classroom, while continuing to concentrate on their school work. The seat discs allow physical movement, while mental motivation is still open for new information in the learning environment. The pillows can be used to sit on during regular class time, testing, group work, project problem solving and quite reading. Vestibular Discs can be an effective option for students who have difficulty focusing by mimicking the movement and shape of an Inflatable ball when used in any sitting position. This is a great addition to the classroom and a great project to support!
needStatement: My students need comfort to promote engagement when learning in the classroom.

name: Paddy Cake, iPaddy Cake
description: My 1st grade students are the most eager learners that I have ever seen. They love all the subjects that they encounter in school, ELA, math, science and art. I want them to be able to continue to have that love for learning. Instead of always learning things the same way all the time, I want my students to gain their knowledge in a fun but appropriate way that they will understand and be able to use all their lives. In this day and age of modern technology, my students need to be able to compete with children all over the world. I want them to be ready for the new technological world that they are expected to live in with complete ease. This iPad will help my students to access reading and math websites that will improve both their academic skills and their computer knowledge. They will discover reading passages and math problems that hopefully will challenge them and raise their curiosity levels. I hope they will be given a chance to use this device and become stronger in their academics.
needStatement: My students need an iPad mini to help them read and develop their technology skills.

name: Practicing Tolerance with Flexible Seating
description: I am spending two consecutive years with my students, this is known as looping. My students are caring, sweet, and a joy to be around. In our second year together, I want my students to focus on maintaining a growth mindset and becoming great problem solvers. Our class is active, we love to read, move, and work with others. First and second grade are pivotal years for student success. My students are learning the foundational skills that are required to become solid readers and mathematicians. My classroom is full of scholars that are eager to learn. After already spending a year with my students in first grade, I know their strengths, weaknesses, and individual needs. Towards the end of first grade, I started offering students the option to sit on the carpet with clipboards, spread out across the rooms, lay down for writing, etc. I could not BELIEVE how much more engaged my students were and how much more work they were able to produce in a short amount of time. After just a couple weeks of introducing seating options to my students, I knew I had to move to a flexible seating classroom!My little scholars love to have choice and freedom; I am learning to let go (some), because of the responsibility and accountability that coincides with choice. I have already received the blessing to ditch my desks for tables, now I just need a variety of seats that will help optimize student learning and attention. I am requesting some comfy chairs and a small rug for students to have additional places to sit and work. My goal is to create different areas (learning zones) that students can choose to work at in a way that best suits their needs. With flexible seating, my students will also learn about tolerance. We will focus on how individuals have different needs; this will promote acceptance of all individuals regardless of their differences.
needStatement: My students need flexible seating options like a rug and beanbags to use during independent work time.

name: Wiggle worms
description: I want my students to have an abundant choice of seating to choose from! Little minds tend to learn better when they feel they have a choice in how they learn and where to sit. I have a class full of bright first graders who are already excited to read and learn. Our school is populated with the majority of students living below the poverty level, but that doesn't stop them from having high goals and expectations. I want to provide for them a friendly, colorful environment in which they can learn without being tied down to a desk! I began thinking about alternative seating as I sat in on the millionth teacher meeting. It started with me moving in my chair because I just could not get comfortable. Then I stood up. Then it was all I could think about. Then the light bulb went off as I said to myself,'If I am this uncomfortable sitting in a regular chair, my mind wandering, how in the world do my elementary school students feel?' This is when I knew I had to make a change. I have always been a teacher that did not care if students needed to move or fidget, as long as they did not disturb anyone else. By providing alternative seating arrangements, I hope to provide all of my students with the choice of a seat that will help them to better concentrate in the school setting and free them from the traditional 'sit and get' mentality that school can have. I am requesting Kids Stay and Play balance balls for each student that can be easily moved around the room and give students the ability to 'get the wiggles out'. Along with the balance balls, students will also have a choice of using wobble cushions on the floor or in a traditional chair, 2 larger 'balloon seats' and a class set of 'fidgets' that are used for kids that just need that something to do with their hands. My goal for this project is that with these choices for my kids, my students can effectively manage their 'need to wiggle' while still growing their minds!
